Vendors`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} and select the relevant
vendor. In the `Accounting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab,
under the `General`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section, update
the `Auto-post bills`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field with one
of the following options:

- `Always`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
- `Ask after 3 validations without edits`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}
- `Never`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}

::: seealso
`Vendor bills matching with purchase orders
<accounting/bill-digitization/vendor-bills-matching-po>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}
:::

## Bill completion {#accounting/vendor_bills/bill-completion}

Whether the bill is created manually or automatically, make sure the
following fields are appropriately completed:

- `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Odoo automatically fills
  in some information based on the information on the vendor\'s contact
  record as well as previous purchase orders and bills.
- `Bill Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Add the sales
  order reference provided by the vendor. This field is used to
  `match <accounting/payments/payments-matching>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"} the products when they are received.
- `Auto-Complete`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select a past
  bill/purchase order to complete the document automatically. The
  `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field should be completed
  before completing this field.
- `Bill Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the document\'s
  issuance date.
- `Accounting Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Update the
  document\'s accounting registration date if needed.
- `Payment Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
  `Memo`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field automatically includes
  the payment reference once the payment is registered.
- `Recipient Bank`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Indicates the
  account number to which the payment will be made. This field is
  required when paying via batch payment files (such as `NACHA
  <l10n_us/ach-electronic-transfers>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} and
  `SEPA <payments/pay_sepa>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}).
- `Due Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
  `Payment Terms`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} must be specified
  for the bill payment.
- `Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select which journal
  should record the bill and in which `currency
  <get_started/multi_currency>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}.

In the `Invoice Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab:

- To access the product catalog, click `Catalog
  </applications/inventory_and_mrp/inventory/warehouses_storage/inventory_management/product_catalog>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}.
- Select the products and quantities, then click
  `Back to Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to return to the
  vendor bill; the selected catalog items will appear in the vendor bill
  lines.
- Update the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
  `Taxes <taxes>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} fields if needed.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If the bill line does not correspond to an existing product in the
database, click `Add
a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and enter a description for
the bill line without linking it to a product.
::::

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Multiple bills for the same purchase order may be issued if the vendor
is on back-order and sends invoices as products are shipped or if the
vendor sends partial bills or requests a deposit. In this case, multiple
bills may have the same `Bill Reference`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.
::::

## Bill confirmation {#accounting/vendor_bills/bill-confirmation}

Click `Confirm`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} when the document is
completed. The status changes to `Posted`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, and a journal entry is generated based on the vendor
bill information. On confirmation, Odoo assigns each vendor bill a
unique number from a defined
`sequence <vendor_bills/sequence>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Once confirmed, a vendor bill can no longer be updated. Click
`Reset to draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} if changes are
required.
::::

## Payment and reconciliation {#accounting/vendor_bills/bill-payment}

To register a payment, click on `Pay`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. In the `Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
window, select the `Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the
`Payment Method`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the
`Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Currency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

When the `Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} paid is less than
the total remaining amount on the vendor bill, the payment is
`partial <accounting/payments/partial-payment>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, and the `Payment
Difference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field displays the
outstanding balance.

The `Memo`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is filled
automatically if the `Payment Reference`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} has been set correctly on the vendor bill. If the field
is empty, select the vendor invoice number as a reference.

Then click `Create payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. An
`In Payment`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}/`Partial`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} banner
appears on the bill until it is
`reconciled <bank/reconciliation>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} and its
status updates to `Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

::: seealso
\- `payments`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} -
`bank/reconciliation`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

## Aged payable report {#accounting/vendor_bills/age-payable-report}

For an overview of the open vendor bills and their due dates, go to
`Accounting -->
Reporting --> Aged payable`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Click the `fa-caret-right`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(right arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon next to a vendor
to view the details of all their outstanding bills, including the due
dates and amounts.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Click `PDF`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`XLSX`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to generate a PDF or XLSX
file, respectively.
::::

::: {.toctree titlesonly=""}
vendor_bills/invoice_digitization vendor_bills/assets
vendor_bills/deferred_expenses vendor_bills/sequence
:::




--- SOURCE: finance/accounting.md ---

show-content

:   

# Accounting and Invoicing

Odoo Invoicing is a standalone app designed to create invoices, send
them to customers, and manage payments. It also handles flows involving
vendor bills. On the other hand, the Accounting app is a comprehensive
accounting solution that allows the same actions and includes additional
features such as standard financial reports, bank reconciliation,
budgets, asset management, and more.

::: seealso
[Odoo Tutorials: Accounting](https://www.odoo.com/slides/accounting-19)
:::

:::::::::: cards
::: {.card target="accounting/get_started" large=""}
Get started

Basic concepts of accounting and initial setup of your accounting
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/taxes"}
Taxes

Taxes, fiscal positions, and integrations
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/customer_invoices"}
Customer invoices

Customer invoices, payment terms, and electronic invoicing
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/vendor_bills"}
Vendor bills

Vendor bills, assets, and invoice digitization (OCR)
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/payments"}
Payments

Invoices and bills payments (online, checks, batches) and follow-up on
invoices
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/bank"}
Bank and cash accounts

Bank synchronization, reconciliation, and cash registers
:::

::: {.card target="accounting/reporting"}
Reporting

Reporting, declarations, and analytic accounting
:::
::::::::::

## Double-entry bookkeeping {#accounting/double-entry-booking}

Odoo automatically creates all the underlying journal entries for all
accounting transactions (e.g., customer invoices, vendor bills,
point-of-sales orders, expenses, inventory valuations, etc.).

Odoo uses the double-entry bookkeeping system, whereby every entry needs
a corresponding and opposite counterpart in a different account, with
one account debited and the other credited. It ensures that all
transactions are recorded accurately and consistently and that the
accounts always balance.

::: seealso
`Accounting Cheat Sheet <accounting/get_started/cheat_sheet>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Accrual and cash basis {#accounting/accrual-cash}

Both accrual and cash basis accounting are supported in Odoo. This
allows reporting income and expense either when the transaction occurs
(accrual basis) or when the payment is made or received (cash basis).

::: seealso
`Cash basis <accounting/taxes/cash_basis>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

## Multi-company {#accounting/multi-company}

`Multiple companies <../general/companies/multi_company>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} can be managed within the same database. Each company has
its own `chart of accounts
<accounting/get_started/chart_of_accounts>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, but `accounts can be shared
<consolidation_account_mapping>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, which is
useful when viewing consolidation reports. Users can view records and
reports from multiple companies simultaneously but can only work on a
single company\'s accounting at a time.

::: seealso
\-
`Multi-company </applications/general/companies/multi_company>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} -
`Inter-company transactions <general/multi-company/inter-company-transactions>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}
:::

## Multi-currency environment {#accounting/multi-currency}

A
`multi-currency <accounting/get_started/multi_currency>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} environment with an automated exchange rate to ease
international transactions is available in Odoo. Every transaction is
recorded in the company\'s default currency; for transactions occurring
in another currency, Odoo stores both the value in the company\'s
currency and the transactions\' currency value. Odoo generates currency
gains and losses after reconciling the journal items.

::: seealso
`Manage a bank in a foreign currency <accounting/bank/foreign_currency>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Branches {#accounting/branches}

Parent `companies </applications/general/companies>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} and their `branches
<general/companies/branches>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} can be
managed within a single database, operating under shared accounting and
reporting rules, including the following:

- The parent company's
  `chart of accounts <accounting/get_started/chart_of_accounts>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"},
  `main currency <accounting/get_started/multi_currency>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}, and `taxes <accounting/taxes>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"} apply to all branches.
- Branches can manage their own dedicated journals and related records.
- The parent company manages a common
  `fiscal period <accounting/year-end/fiscal-years>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}, so its
  `lock and closing dates <accounting/year-end/lock-everything-date>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"} apply across all branches. However, branches may set
  earlier lock dates if needed.
- The parent company can access all
  `reports <accounting/reporting>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"},
  `invoices
  <accounting/customer_invoices>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"},
  `bills <accounting/vendor_bills>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, etc.,
  from its branches, while each branch can only view its own data.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `Fiscal localization <fiscal_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} package is set on the parent company.
::::

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

Adding a branch to a company enables `multi-company functions
<../general/companies/multi_company>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}.

For more information, refer to [Odoo\'s pricing
page](https://www.odoo.com/pricing-plan) or contact your Odoo account
manager.
::::

### Reporting {#accounting/branch/reporting}

The parent company consolidates accounting operations from all branches,
providing a centralized view of
`financial reports <accounting/reporting>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, such as profit and loss or balance sheets.

### VAT {#accounting/branch/vat}

Each company and branch must be configured with its own legal
information, including a VAT number when applicable. Depending on the
structure, branches may share the parent company\'s VAT number or have
their own, resulting in a common or separate `VAT return
<accounting/reporting/tax_returns>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}.

This flexible setup allows users to generate individual reports and tax
returns for each entity if needed.

## International standards {#accounting/international-standards}

Odoo Accounting supports over 100 countries and provides standardized
features and mechanisms applicable across all regions. Country-specific
modules are included to comply with local accounting regulations.
`Fiscal localizations <fiscal_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} handle regional requirements, such as charts of accounts,
taxes, or any other legal obligations.

## Accounts receivable and payable {#accounting/accounts-receivable-payable}

By default, one account is designated for accounts receivable entries
and another for accounts payable entries. As transactions are linked to
**contacts**, it is possible to run a report per customer, vendor, or
supplier.

The **Partner Ledger** report displays the balance of customers and
suppliers. To access it, go to
`Accounting --> Reporting --> Partner Ledger`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

## Reporting {#accounting/reporting}

The following financial
`reports <accounting/reporting>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} are
available and updated in real-time:

+------------------------------------------------------------+
| > Financial reports                                        |
+=========================+==================================+
| Statement               | Balance sheet                    |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Profit and loss                  |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Cash flow statement              |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Executive summary                |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Tax return                       |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | EC sales list                    |
+-------------------------+----------------------------------+
| Audit                   | General ledger                   |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Trial balance                    |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Journal audit                    |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Intrastat report                 |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Check register                   |
+-------------------------+----------------------------------+
| Partner                 | Partner ledger                   |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Aged receivable                  |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Aged payable                     |
+-------------------------+----------------------------------+
| Management              | Invoice analysis                 |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Analytic report                  |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Audit trail                      |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Budget report                    |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Unrealized currency gains/losses |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Deferred revenue                 |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Deferred expense                 |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Depreciation schedule            |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Disallowed expenses              |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Loans analysis                   |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | Product margins                  |
|                         +----------------------------------+
|                         | 1099 report                      |
+-------------------------+----------------------------------+

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

`Create and customize reports <accounting/reporting/customize>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} with Odoo\'s report engine.
::::

### Tax return {#accounting/tax-report}

In the `Tax return <accounting/tax-returns/report>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, Odoo computes all accounting transactions for the specific
tax period and uses these totals to calculate the tax obligation.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Depending on the country\'s localization, an XML version of the tax
report can be generated to be uploaded to the VAT platform of the
relevant taxation authority.
::::

## Bank synchronization {#accounting/bank-synchronization}

The bank synchronization system directly connects with banking
institutions to automatically import all transactions into the database.
It gives an overview of the cash flow without logging into an online
banking system or waiting for paper bank statements.

::: seealso
`Bank synchronization <accounting/bank/bank_synchronization>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Inventory valuation {#accounting/inventory-valuation}

Both periodic (manual) and perpetual (automated) inventory valuations
are supported in Odoo. The available methods are Standard Price, Average
Cost (AVCO), and First In First Out (FIFO).

::: seealso
`../inventory_and_mrp/inventory/inventory_valuation/cheat_sheet`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Retained earnings {#accounting/retained-earnings}

Retained earnings are the portion of income retained by a business. Odoo
calculates current year earnings in real-time, so no year-end journal or
rollover is required. The profit and loss balance is automatically
reported on the balance sheet report.

::: seealso
`Accounting Cheat Sheet <accounting/get_started/cheat_sheet>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Fiduciaries {#accounting/fiduciaries}

The `Accounting Firms`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} mode can be
activated by going to `Accounting -->
Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
When enabled:

- The document\'s sequence becomes editable on all documents;
- The `Total (tax incl.)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field
  appears to speed up and control the encoding by automating line
  creation with the right account and tax;
- `Invoice Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
  `Bill Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} are pre-filled when
  encoding a transaction.
- A `Quick encoding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option is
  available for customer invoices and vendor bills.

## Accountant access rights {#accounting/accountant-access-rights}

To grant access to the company\'s accountant,
`add the accountant as a new user
<users/add-individual>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} and configure the
appropriate `access rights
<../general/users/access_rights>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} in the
`Accounting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section to enable access
to the company\'s financial data:

- `Accounting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select
  `Administrator`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- `Bank`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Allow bank account
  validation.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Adding an accountant as a new user in
`Odoo Online <../../administration/odoo_online>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} is free if the accountant has an Odoo account registered
with the same email address as the one listed for the company user.
However, `Odoo.sh <../../administration/odoo_sh>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} and
`Odoo On-premise <../../administration/on_premise>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} may involve extra charges for each additional user. For more
pricing information, see [Odoo\'s
pricing](https://www.odoo.com/pricing-plan).
::::

For a multi-company environment, set the appropriate
`access <users/multi-companies>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

::: {.toctree titlesonly=""}
accounting/get_started accounting/taxes accounting/customer_invoices
accounting/vendor_bills accounting/payments accounting/bank
accounting/reporting
:::




--- SOURCE: finance/esg.md ---

# ESG

The ESG (Environment, Social, and Governance) app helps you automate ESG
data collection by integrating with apps like Accounting, Fleet,
Payroll, and Employees. It pulls data from your operations to build your
ESG reports, based on legal and sustainability reporting requirements,
while giving you a real-time view of your emissions and other key ESG
metrics.

## Carbon footprint

The carbon footprint tool automates emissions tracking by collecting
data from accounting records (purchases, expenses, etc.) and employee
commuting activity, and supports manual inputs. Emissions are updated in
real time, allowing for continuous monitoring and reporting. You can:

- Track your daily environmental impact.
- Evaluate the immediate effect of your reduction actions.
- Prioritize targeted changes.
- Continuously monitor and refine your sustainability strategy.

::: admonition
Emissions (kgCOâ‚‚e) formula

[Activity data]{.title-ref} Ã— [Emission factor]{.title-ref}
:::

### Activity data sources

The following data sources are used:

- `Accounting <esg/accounting>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
- `Fleet <esg/fleet>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
- `Manual inputs <esg/manual>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}

#### Accounting {#esg/accounting}

Odoo collects activity data from journal entries posted to expense and
asset accounts. These include:

- Fixed assets
- Expenses
- Other expenses
- Cost of revenue

Only these account types are considered for carbon footprint
calculations, in line with the *Bilan Carbone* methodology.

#### Fleet {#esg/fleet}

Odoo calculates commuting emissions using data from the Fleet and
Employees apps.

::: admonition
Employee commuting emissions formula

[Days]{.title-ref} Ã— [Home-work distance]{.title-ref} Ã— [2]{.title-ref}
Ã— ([Number of office days]{.title-ref} / [7]{.title-ref}) Ã— [Vehicle
model COâ‚‚ emissions]{.title-ref}
:::

To ensure accurate calculations:

- Define the average number of days per week the employees commute to
  the office by going to
  `ESG --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
  role="menuselection"} and filling in the `Weekly Office
  Attendance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- Set the emissions of each vehicle model by going to
  `Fleet --> Configuration -->
  Models`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, selecting a model,
  and entering its `COâ‚‚ Emissions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- Set each employee\'s home-to-work distance by opening the
  `Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} app, selecting an
  employee, and filling in the employee\'s
  `Home-Work Distance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The employee vehicle\'s `Start Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
and, if applicable, `End Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, are
used to calculate the emissions. Ensure they are set by opening the
`Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} app, selecting an
employee, and clicking the `Cars`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
smart button.
::::

To access the employee commuting emissions pivot table, go to
`ESG --> Collect -->
Employee Commuting`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

![The employee commuting emissions pivot table](esg/employee-commuting-pivot.png)

To add the data to the emitted emissions, click
`Add Emissions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, define the
`Emissions Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} that should be
covered, and click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

#### Manual input {#esg/manual}

You can manually enter emissions for activities that not tracked
automatically (e.g., employee lunches, waste, etc.). To do so, go to
`ESG --> Collect --> Emitted Emissions`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and click `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, then:

- Name the activity.
- Select a `Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- Select an `Emission factor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- Enter a `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Once saved, the entry appears under
`ESG --> Collect --> Emitted Emissions`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and is included in the carbon footprint report.

### Emission factors

An emission factor is a coefficient that indicates the rate at which a
specific activity emits greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

#### Source database

Import the data from a certified emission factors database by going to
`ESG -->
Configuration --> Source Databases`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Click `Download`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} on the
[ADEME](https://www.ademe.fr/en/our-missions/data) database to import
its emission factors and sources.

#### Main components of an emission factor

##### Source

Each emission factor is assigned to a scope, following the GHG Protocol:

- Scope 1 -- Direct emissions (e.g., fuel burned on-site or in company
  vehicles)
- Scope 2 -- Indirect emissions from purchased energy (e.g., electricity
  or heat)
- Scope 3 -- All other indirect emissions across the value chain (e.g.,
  purchased goods, travel, waste)

Scopes can be structured hierarchically (parent-child) for more detailed
categorization, such as \"Scope 3: Others Indirect \> Purchased Goods \>
Electronics\".

##### Uncertainty

Uncertainty represents the potential margin of error in an emission
factor. It reflects how precise or reliable the factor is when
estimating emissions for a given activity, based on the quality of data,
assumptions used, and calculation methodology.

It helps you assess the confidence level of the emissions data used in
the reporting.

##### Compute method

The compute method determines whether emissions are calculated using
physical quantities (e.g., kg, liters, units) or monetary values (e.g.,
â‚¬ spent). In physical mode, the system uses the quantity from the
transaction (e.g., 10 units Ã— `EF (emission factor)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} per unit). In monetary mode, it uses the transaction amount
(e.g., â‚¬500 Ã— `EF (emission factor)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} per
â‚¬).

##### Gas emissions lines

Each emission factor can include multiple gas emission lines,
representing the different greenhouse gases involved in the activity.
The ESG app includes the six main gases from the Kyoto Protocol --- COâ‚‚,
CHâ‚„, Nâ‚‚O, HFCs, PFCs, SFâ‚† --- each with a predefined Global Warming
Potential (GWP) used to convert them into a common unit: COâ‚‚-equivalent
(kgCOâ‚‚e).

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Add more specific gases by going to
`ESG --> Configuration --> Gases`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.
::::

Each gas line can be linked to an activity type such as production,
transport, or use, allowing for detailed breakdowns in your emissions
reporting.

The final emission factor value is the sum of all these gases' emissions
converted into COâ‚‚-equivalents.

#### Assignation rules

Assignation rules allow emission factors to be automatically applied to
relevant activity data based on specific criteria: the product, partner,
and/or account involved in the transaction.

::: example
You have assigned an emission factor to the *Zenith Pro Computer*
product and later receive a vendor bill for 150 units; the system
automatically applies the assigned emission factor, multiplying the
emission factor\'s emissions (kgCOâ‚‚e) by 150.
:::

To define assignation rules on emissions factors, go to
`ESG --> Configuration -->
Emission Factors`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} and select an
emission factor. Under the `Assignations`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab, click `Add a line`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, and select a record for one or more of the following
attributes: `Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Partner`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

All attributes have to match for the rule to be applied.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

Ensure the unit of measure set next to the product\'s
`Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} matches the emission factor\'s
`Unit of Measure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![A product\'s unit of measure](esg/product-unit-of-measure.png)

If the field is not displayed, go to
`Accounting --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and enable the
`Units of Measure & Packagings`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
option.
::::

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Accounting journal entries with a missing emission factor can be found
by clicking `Emissions to define`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
under the `Collect Emissions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} card on
the dashboard.
::::

##### Rules priority

When multiple assignation rules match, Odoo prioritizes the most
specific rule based on the following criteria:

1.  Attribute specificity: Odoo first evaluates rules by the most
    precise attribute, following this priority hierarchy (from most to
    least specific):
    1.  Product
    2.  Partner
    3.  Account
2.  Attribute count: if multiple rules share the same level of attribute
    specificity, Odoo then considers the number of attributes in the
    rule. The rule with more attributes defined will take priority.

::: example
**Example 1**

*Emission factor #1 assignation rule*

  Account         Partner         Product
  --------------- --------------- -------------------------
  *Any Account*   *Any Partner*   **Zenith Pro Computer**

*Emission factor #2 assignation rule*

  Account         Partner           Product
  --------------- ----------------- ---------------
  *Any Account*   **Digital Den**   *Any Product*

Given the assignation rules above, all products purchased from **Digital
Den** will be assigned emission factor **#2**, except the **Zenith Pro
Computer** product, which will be assigned emission factor **#1**.

**Example 2**

*Emission factor #1 assignation rule*

  Account         Partner         Product
  --------------- --------------- -------------------------
  *Any Account*   *Any Partner*   **Zenith Pro Computer**

*Emission factor #2 assignation rule*

  Account         Partner           Product
  --------------- ----------------- -------------------------
  *Any Account*   **Digital Den**   **Zenith Pro Computer**

Given the assignation rules above, any purchased **Zenith Pro Computer**
will be assigned emission factor **#1**, except if purchased from the
**Digital Den**, which will be assigned emission factor **#2**.
:::

##### Apply retroactively

Once your emission factors are configured with assignation rules, you
can also apply them retroactively to past activity data.

To do so, go to
`ESG -->  Configuration --> Emission Factors`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, select an emission factor, and click
`Assign`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Select an
`Application Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and, if
desired, enable the `Replace existing assignations`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} option.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Apply emission factors in bulk by selecting multiple emission factors in
`oi-view-list`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} list view and clicking
`fa-cog`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} (`Actions`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}) `--> Assign Emission
Factors`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
::::

## Sex parity and pay gap

Sex parity tracks the distribution of sexes across the workforce, such
as comparing women and men in technical vs. administrative roles,
permanent vs. temporary contracts, different office locations, or
management vs. non-management positions.

These insights, based on employee data, are essential for CSRD reporting
under ESRS S1 and will also support future VSME standards.

To view a company\'s sex parity and pay gap measures, set the sex of
each employee by opening the `Employees`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} app and selecting an employee. Under the
`Private Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, select the
employee\'s `Gender`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

The pay gap is calculated using the wages set on the employees\' Payroll
contracts for the same jobs.

::: admonition
Pay gap formula

(([Average male salary]{.title-ref} -- [Average female
salary]{.title-ref}) / [Average male salary]{.title-ref}) Ã—
[100]{.title-ref}
:::

Access the measures by clicking
`ESG --> Measure --> Sex Parity / Pay Gap`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Use the different `Group By <search/group>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} options to break down the data by
`Leadership Level`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Department`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Job Position`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Contract Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
`Country`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![The sex parity graph filtering options](esg/sex-graph-group-by.png)
::::

## Initiatives

Go to `ESG --> Act --> Initiatives`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} to access all the `Project
<../services/project>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} features, and start
taking action on your impact. You can estimate COâ‚‚ savings for each
task, track progress, and assign team members with deadlines.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Estimated COâ‚‚ reductions do not immediately lower your carbon footprint.
The real impact shows only when these reductions are reflected in your
operations.
::::




--- SOURCE: finance/expenses/approve_expenses.md ---

# Approve expenses

In Odoo, most users cannot approve expenses; only users with the
necessary `access rights
<../../general/users/access_rights>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} or
permissions can. This means that a user **must** have at least *Team
Approver* rights for the **Expenses** app. Employees with the necessary
rights can review expenses, approve or refuse them, and provide feedback
with an integrated `Refuse Expense
<expenses/refuse-report>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} communication
tool.

Please refer to the
`access rights documentation </applications/general/users>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} to learn more about managing users and their access rights.

## View expense reports

Users who are able to approve expense reports (typically managers) have
an `Expense
Reports`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} main navigation button at
the top of the **Expenses** app. This allows managers to view all
expense reports they have access rights for. Navigate to
`Expenses app --> Expense
Reports`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, to view the
`All Reports`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard.

A list of all expense reports with a status of either
`To Submit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Submitted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Approved`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Posted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or `Done`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} appears. Expense reports with a status of
`Refused`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} are hidden, by default.

![Reports to validate are found on the Reports to Approve page.](approve_expenses/expense-reports-list.png)

## Approve expense reports

Expense reports can be approved in two ways:
`individually <expenses/individual>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} or
`in
bulk <expenses/multiple>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

Only reports with a status of `Submitted`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} can be approved.

It is recommended to display only `Submitted`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} reports by ticking the checkbox beside the
`Submitted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} filter, in the left
column, under the `Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section.

If a report is **not** able to be approved, the
`Approve Report`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button **does not**
appear on the `All Reports`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page.
::::

### Approve individual reports {#expenses/individual}

To approve an individual report, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Expense Reports`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click on an individual report to view the
detailed report form.

From here, several options are presented: `Approve`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Refuse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Reset to draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Click
`Approve`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to approve the report.

> ![An individual expense report that can be approved or refused.](approve_expenses/approve-individual.png)

### Approve multiple reports {#expenses/multiple}

To approve multiple expense reports at once, first navigate to
`Expenses app -->
Expense Reports`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} to view a list
of expense reports. Next, select the reports to approve by ticking the
checkbox next to each report being approved, or tick the checkbox next
to the `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column title to
select all the reports in the list.

Next, click the `Approve Report`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button.

> ![Select multiple expense reports at once.](approve_expenses/approve-multiple.png)

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Team managers can view all the expense reports for their team members
only. While on the `All Reports`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
page, click the `fa-caret-down`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(down arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to the right of the
search bar, then click `My Team`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in
the `fa-filter`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Filters`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section. This presents all
the reports for only the manager\'s team.
::::

## Refuse expense reports {#expenses/refuse-report}

Expense reports can **only** be refused on the individual expense
report, and **not** from the `All Reports`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard. To open an individual expense report,
navigate to `Expenses app --> Expense Reports`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, then click on an individual expense report to
view the detailed expense report form.

If more information is needed, such as a missing receipt, communicate
any necessary information requests in the *chatter* of the report form.
On the individual expense report, click either
`Send message`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Log note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to open a message text
box.

Type in a message, tagging the proper people, and post it to the
*chatter* by clicking `Send`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Log`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, depending on the method of
communication. The message is posted in the chatter, and the tagged
people are notified via email.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The only people that can be tagged in a message are *followers* of the
specific report. To see who is a follower, click the
`fa-user-o`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(Show Followers)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon to display
the followers of the expense report.

![Send messages in the chatter.](approve_expenses/chatter.png)
::::

To refuse an expense report, click `Refuse`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, and a `Refuse Expense`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads. Enter a brief explanation for the
refusal on the `Reason`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} line, then
click `Refuse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![Send messages in the chatter.](approve_expenses/refuse-expense.png)

Once the expense report is refused, the status changes to
`Refused`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the only button that
appears is `Reset to Draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.




--- SOURCE: finance/expenses/expense_cards.md ---

# Expense cards

Odoo offers physical and virtual expense cards, allowing for better
expense tracking and management. Using expense cards allows for real
time expense management, creating expense records as soon as an expense
transaction occurs, allowing management greater visibility of expense
costs as they are incurred.

The elimination of the need to
`actively create expense records <log_expenses>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} allows for a more streamlined expense workflow, with records
automatically created as purchases are made.

To use expense cards, first a
`card is configured <expenses/card-configure>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, then it is
`activated <expenses/card-activate>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
Before employees can make purchases with their expense card, a
`Stripe account must be created <expenses/create-stripe>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} and configured, then
`funds must be added <expenses/add-funds>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
to the company\'s Stripe account. Once there is money available in the
account (this typically takes 2-3 business days for the transfer to
Stripe), employees can use their expense cards, and the money is pulled
from the company\'s Stripe account.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

To create and use expense cards, both the **Accounting** and
**Invoicing** apps **must** be
`installed <general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

To access confidential card data (card number and CVV for virtual cards;
PIN for physical cards), the employee **must** have a
`user <../../general/users>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} profile.
These details can **only** be accessed through that profile.
::::

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Expense cards act like pre-paid debit cards, as they can **only** be
used with a connected Stripe account, and **only** if funds are added to
that account, to be drawn from.
::::

## Availability

Expense cards are currently available for the following countries:

  ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------
  Austria       Belgium       Croatia       Cyprus

  Estonia       Finland       France        Germany

  Greece        Ireland       Italy         Latvia

  Lithuania     Luxembourg    Malta         Netherlands

  Portugal      Slovakia      Slovenia      Spain
  ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------

Only companies located in one of these countries are able to create and
use expense cards.

## Fees

Odoo covers **all fees** associated with creating virtual and physical
cards.

## Configuration {#expenses/card-settings}

Two settings must be configured to use expense cards. Navigate to
`Expenses app -->
Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
Tick the box next to `Expense Card`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
then click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. The
`Settings`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page reloads, and two
fields now appear beneath the `Expense Card`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} option.

A `Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field with
`Stripe Issuing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} appears, populating
the field. This is the default journal, and it is **not** recommended to
alter this unless instructed by the accounting department.

Next, click the text link `terms and conditions`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} and an `Expense Cards Terms and
Conditions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads, with
all the details of the agreement. After this has been read, click
`Close`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, then tick the checkbox next
to `I confirm agreeing to the terms
and conditions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to accept the terms,
then click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The terms and conditions **must** be agreed to use expense cards.
::::

After agreeing to the terms and conditions,
`create a Stripe connected account
<expenses/create-stripe>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

## Create Stripe connected account {#expenses/create-stripe}

To create a Stripe connected account, open the **Expenses** app, and
ensure the `Expense
Card`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option is enabled. Next, click
`oi-arrow-right`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Connect`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to create a new Stripe
Issuing connect account.

Fill in the KYC questionnaire provided by Stripe. Stripe takes +/-24
hours to approve or refuse account creation requests.

A green `Verified`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tag now appears
next to `oi-arrow-left`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Refresh`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, indicating the account is
properly configured.

Once the account is verified, the company must
`add funds <expenses/add-funds>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} to their
Stripe balance.

## Add funds to Stripe account {#expenses/add-funds}

For employees to use their expense cards, funds must be available in the
company\'s Stripe account, to make purchases against. To add funds to
the company\'s Stripe account, open the **Accounting** app. On the
`Stripe Issuing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} Kanban card, click
`Top-up`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and a
`Top-up`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads.

Enter the amount being transferred into the account in the
`Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field. The
`IBAN`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and `BIC`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} fields are populated according to the Stripe
configuration and cannot be changed. When configured, click
`Topup`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the transfer is
initiated.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The user wires money to the IBAN shown using a SEPA Credit Transfer (for
the EURO Zone). The Stripe issuing partner bank is [Circle
Bank]{.title-ref}.
::::

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

It typically takes 2-3 business days for transfers to be processed.
Funds are **not** available until the transfer is complete.
::::

## Configure expense cards {#expenses/card-configure}

To create and configure a new expense card, click
`Cards`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} in the main **Expenses**
app menu to view the `Cards`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
dashboard. Click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and a blank
`Cards`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form loads. Enter the
following information on the form:

- `Card Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The first line on the
  card form is blank, and displays [Draft]{.title-ref}. Enter a name for
  the card in this field. This does **not** need to be a person\'s name,
  it can be something descriptive to explain the use of the card.

  ::: example
  An employee is going on a week-long business trip to Berlin to visit
  many clients. The employee needs to pay for meals, transportation, and
  other business-related expenses. Since this is a short trip, a virtual
  card is created to capture all the expenses, with the name [Business
  Trip - Berlin]{.title-ref}.

  The marketing department pays for many expenses throughout the year,
  from email marketing services, venue rentals for events, promotional
  merchandise, etc. Since the expenses do not have an end date, and it
  is used for an entire department, a physical card is ordered with the
  name [Marketing]{.title-ref}.
  :::

- `Cardholder`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the person
  using the card from the drop-down menu. Once selected, the person\'s
  name populates the `Draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field,
  above `Cardholder`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

- `Update info`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Next to the
  cardholder\'s name, click `Update info`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} and a `Cardholder Configuration`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads. Update the cardholder\'s name,
  birthday, phone number, email, and physical address. All the requested
  information **must** be populated, as it is used to create the expense
  card with Stripe, and to verify the cardholder\'s identity, when
  needed. If any information is missing from this form, the card
  **cannot** be created, and an error appears when creating or ordering
  the card.

  :::: important
  ::: title
  Important
  :::

  The phone number listed is used for two-factor authentication. The
  phone number can be changed in the future. When changing the phone
  number, an alert is sent to the original phone number, notifying them
  of the change.
  ::::

- `Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Click the radio button next
  to the desired *type* of expense card. Options are:

  - `Physical`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A physical card is
    printed and mailed out to the employee. If selected, a
    `Delivery Address`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field appears.
    Using the drop-down menu, select the employee or company address the
    card is mailed to.
  - `Virtual`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Virtual cards are
    available instantaneously once the card configuration is completed
    and the card is activated.

- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the company the
  expenses are associated with using the drop-down menu. Each card must
  be associated with a single company, and are **not** available for use
  between all companies or branches in the database. Ensure the selected
  company has its own Stripe Connect account configured, or the expense
  cards will not work.

- `Stripe Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  `Stripe Issuing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} populates this
  field by default, and cannot be modified.

Next, configure the following fields in the
`Spending Policy`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab of the card
form:

- `Countries`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the countries the card is able to be used in. The
  company\'s country location populates this field, by default. All
  other countries the employee may travel to or purchase expensable
  items from, should be included in this list.

- `Categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If the expense card
  is limited to purchase items within a specific *category*, select them
  using the drop-down menu. If this field is left blank, the card may be
  used for *any* expense category.

  Odoo is able to categorize transactions based on the
  `MCC (Merchant Category Code)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} provided
  by the card network provider (such as Mastercard). Every merchant has
  a corresponding `MCC
  (Merchant Category Code)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} that
  identifies their business and product types. When a Stripe-issued card
  is used, the `MCC (Merchant Category Code)`{.interpreted-text
  role="abbr"} is sent with the transaction, allowing Stripe to approve
  or block it based on the card\'s configuration.

  ::: example
  A company issues an expense card that is only authorized for airline,
  train, and taxi travel expenses.

  To configure this, click into the `Category`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} field, and click `Search
  more...`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at the bottom. In the
  `Search: Categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window,
  click into the search bar and click
  `Transportation services`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the
  `fa-filter`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} `Filters`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} column.

  Next, tick the checkboxes next to the desired transportation
  categories. In this example, only `Railroads`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}, `Passenger Railways`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}, `Taxicabs Limousines`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}, and `Airlines Air Carriers`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} are selected.

  Click `Select`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the selected
  transportation categories now populate the
  `Categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.
  :::

- `Limit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Configure the two spending
  limits for the card. The first configuration sets the total expense
  amount allowed during a specific time period. Using the drop-down menu
  after the word `per`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, select the
  time period the limit applies to. The available options are:
  `Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Week`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}, `Month`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Year`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
  `All Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Next, enter the maximum
  amount allowed for the selected time period.

  Next, set the *per transaction* limit. Enter the maximum amount that
  can be charged on the expense card in a single transaction in the
  field.

  ::: example
  A company allows employees to purchase airline tickets that are less
  than \$1,000.00 total. Additionally, there is a monthly cap of
  \$3,000.00 for all expenses.

  The company would configure the limit as follows:
  [3,000.00]{.title-ref} per `Month`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
  and [1,000.00]{.title-ref} per transaction.
  :::

:::::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Card limits can be modified at any point. Once modified, they
immediately go into effect.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

All expense cards pull payments from a single Stripe account. It is
recommended to set card limits to avoid large charges or transactions
that may prematurely deplete the expense Stripe account.
::::
::::::

![An expense card form filled out for transportation and food only.](expense_cards/card-form.png)

## Activate expense cards {#expenses/card-activate}

Once an expense card is configured, the next step is to activate the
cards. First, navigate to `Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and the `Cards`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard loads, displaying all expense cards in a
Kanban view.

All cards display their status on a banner in the upper-right corner of
each card. Statuses are either:

- `Draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The card form is filled
  out, but the card has not been requested or activated.
- `Pending`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A physical card has been
  ordered, but not activated.
- `Active`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The card is able to be
  used. This status does **not** display a status banner on the card.
- `Paused`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A card has been put *on
  hold* and no transactions can be processed with this status.
- `Blocked`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The physical or virtual
  card is *cancelled* and cannot be used.

Click on a card to activate, and the card form loads. Ensure all the
fields are `configured
<expenses/card-configure>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, then click
either `Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} if requesting a
physical card, or `Activate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} if
creating a virtual card.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Physical cards take 5 to 10 business days to be delivered. Once ordered,
delivery information is added to the chatter, and the user who placed
the card order receives the information by email.
::::

If a physical card is requested, the card status changes to
`Inactive`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, while it is being printed
and mailed to the selected address. Once the card arrives, follow the
included instructions to activate the card.

If the card is a virtual card, once `Activate`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} is clicked, the status changes to
`Active`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and it is available for use.

Once the status of an expense card is `Active`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, the user can use the card to purchase expensable
items, as long as the purchases are within the limits set on the card.

## Demo expense card

To test the expense card feature without using a live Stripe account,
`install
<general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} the [Expense Cards:
Demo]{.title-ref} module. This replaces production functionalities and
allows for the creation of a demo Stripe account, using virtual cards
and fake funds to simulate transactions.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If a production account is already configured, **do not use** the demo
module, as it overwrites the existing setup.
::::

## Using expense cards

Using an expense card is almost identical to using any other credit or
debit card. The only difference is if a
`physical card <expenses/physical>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} or a
`virtual card
<expenses/virtual>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} is used.

When a charge is made using an expense card, an expense record is
automatically created in the **Expenses** app, linked to the specific
card. The next step is to attach the corresponding receipt.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

It is best proactive to take a photo of a receipt as soon as it is
received, to eliminate the risk of losing the receipt and having an
expense reimbursement request denied.
::::

Open the expense record by navigating to
`Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and
click on the specific card. Next, click the `fa-usd`{.interpreted-text
role="icon"} `Expenses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart button,
and the `Expenses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard loads
for that card. Any expense that does *not* have a receipt attached to
the record displays a `fa-credit-card`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Please upload the receipt.`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}

Click on the desired expense record to open the detailed expense form.
Click the `Attach
Receipt`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and a file explorer
loads. Navigate to the receipt, and click `Open`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to select it and attach it to the expense.

Make any other adjustments to
`the expense record <expenses/manual_expense>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, if necessary. Once the record is correct, click
`Submit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to submit the receipt, or
`Split`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, if the receipt needs to be
split between multiple expenses.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

If a purchase is attempted that either is outside the listed countries,
listed categories, or exceeds the transaction limit or total expense
limit for the specified time period, the expense is denied and captured
in the `Expenses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard for the
card, with a status of *Refused*.

To view the details of why the transaction was refused, click on the
`fa-usd`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} `Expenses`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} smart button for the card, and click on the refused
transaction. The details explaining why the transaction was refused
appears in the chatter, authored by *OdooBot*.
::::

## Physical card {#expenses/physical}

When using a physical card, make charges in the same manner as a regular
physical pre-paid debit card.

Once the user receives the card, the cardholder must activate the card
using the instructions provided with the card. Next, open the
**Expenses** app, and click on the physical card, which has a status of
`Pending`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Click
`Activate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, then when prompted, enter
the last four digits of the card, confirm the phone number, accept the
terms and conditions, and complete the activation.

### Card PIN

To view the card\'s PIN, the cardholder **must** have a
`user <../../general/users>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} profile.
Navigate to `Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click on the card to open the card form.
Enter the six-digit code sent via SMS to the associated phone number.
The card and its PIN appear in a pop-up window. The PIN is displayed
below the card and **cannot** be changed.

## Virtual card {#expenses/virtual}

If using a virtual card, the cardholder **must** have a
`user <../../general/users>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} profile to
access the card information required for purchases.

To obtain the card information, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} and
click on the virtual card being used. Next, click into the
`Card Details`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, and two items
appear: the expense card number, with only the last four digits
displayed, and the expiration date.

To view the full details, click `fa-eye`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`View Details`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and a `Two-Factor
Authentication`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads.
Enter the six-digit authentication code that is texted to the
cardholder\'s phone number. The card appears in the pop-up window, with
all the information displayed: the card number, expiration date, and
security code. When done, close the window by clicking
`X`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Android users can add their virtual expense cards [to a Google
wallet](https://support.google.com/wallet/answer/12058983?hl=en).
::::

## Lost cards

When a physical card is lost, or if credentials for a virtual card have
been compromised, the cards must be updated in the **Expenses** app so
they cannot be used. This is referred to in Odoo as *blocking*.

To stop any charges on a card, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and
click on the specific card being deactivated. On the card form, click
the `Block`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and a
`Block a Card`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window loads.

Click into the field next to `Reason`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, and select the reason the card is being blocked. The
options are `Lost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Stolen`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
`Other`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. After making a selection,
click `Block`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the card is unable
to be used, and a red `Blocked`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
banner appears on the card in the `Cards`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard view.

::: example
An employee is given a virtual expense card to use for an upcoming
business trip. The employee uses this card to purchase an airline ticket
and a hotel room, one month before the scheduled trip.

A week before the trip, they receive an email from the airline,
explaining there has been a data breach, and customer names, contact
information, and purchase details including credit card numbers have
been leaked.

The employee reaches out to their manager, explaining the situation. The
manager opens the virtual expense card, and blocks the card using the
reason `Other`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then the manager
issues another virtual card for the employee to use for their business
trip.
:::

## Temporary card pauses

When an employee is out of office for an extended period of time, such
as a vacation, or an illness, it is recommended to temporarily
deactivate their card to prevent any fraudulent charges. This is
referred to in Odoo as *pausing* a card.

To pause a card, navigate to `Expenses app --> Cards`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click on the specific card being paused. On
the card form, click `Pause`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
card is unable to be used until it is activated.

::: example
An employee in the sales department has a physical expense card to use
for client meetings. They recently welcomed a new child, and will be out
of office on parental leave for three months.

On the employee\'s last day, their manager opens the expense card
record, and clicks `Pause`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. When the
employee returns to work, the manager opens the expense card form and
clicks `Active`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to reactivate the
card.
:::




--- SOURCE: finance/expenses/expense_categories.md ---

# Expense categories

Odoo **Expenses** streamlines the management of expenses. After an
employee `logs
<../expenses/log_expenses>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} and
`submits <../expenses/submit_expenses>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
their expenses in Odoo, expenses are reviewed by management and
accounting teams. Once `approved
<../expenses/approve_expenses>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, payments
can be processed and `disbursed back to the employee
<../expenses/reimburse>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} for
reimbursement.

::: seealso
[Odoo Expenses: product page](https://www.odoo.com/app/expenses)
:::

## View expense categories

The first step to track expenses is configuring the different types of
expenses for the company (managed as *expense categories* in Odoo). Each
category can be as specific or generalized as needed. Additionally,
expense categories can be configured to repay expenses at either a set
price or allow for specific prices to be reported.

To view the default expense categories, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Configuration
--> Expense Categories`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

The default expense categories allow creating expenses for common
expenses, including communication costs, meals, gifts, miles driven, and
other travel expenses. For expenses outside these default categories,
the general expenses category, `EXP_GEN`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, is used. If a company has specific expenses it
commonly reimburses, and wants to track them separately,
`new expense categories
can be made <expenses/new-category>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} or
existing expense categories can be modified.

![Set expense costs on products.](expense_categories/default-categories.png)

## Create new expense categories {#expenses/new-category}

Some companies require more expense categories than the **Expenses** app
includes. For these situations, new expense categories can be created.

::: example
A company that trains car mechanics allows its technicians to purchase
\$500 worth of tools in a year. In this situation, the company creates a
new category called [TOOLS]{.title-ref} to track all tool expenses.
:::

To create a new expense category, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Configuration -->
Expense Categories`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Click
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and a new expense category
form loads.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Expense *categories* are managed like *products* in Odoo. The expense
category form follows the standard product form in Odoo, and the
information entered is similar. Expense *products* are referred to as
expense *categories* throughout this document since the main menu refers
to these as `Expense Categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
::::

Enter the following fields on the form:

- `Product Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a name for
  the category that is short and informative.

- `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If employees can report the
  actual cost of an expense, and are reimbursed the reported amount,
  leave the field set to [0.00]{.title-ref}. If the expense should
  **always** be reimbursed for a specific price, enter the amount in
  this field. If a price is entered, a `per`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} field appears with `Unit`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} populated by default. `Unit`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} covers most expense situations, but if the
  reimbursement is based on weight, length, volume, etc., choose the
  corresponding type of unit using the drop-down menu.

  ::: example
  Here are some examples for when to set a specific
  `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} on a product vs. leaving the
  `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at \`0.00\`:

  - **Meals**: If employees are reimbursed for their full meal cost, set
    the `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to [0.00]{.title-ref}.
    When an employee logs an expense for a meal, they enter the actual
    amount of the bill and are reimbursed for that amount. An expense
    for a meal costing \$95.23 would equal a reimbursement of \$95.23.
  - **Mileage**: If employees receive a flat rate for each mile they
    drive, set the `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to
    [1.00]{.title-ref}. When an employee logs an expense for the miles
    driven, they enter the number of miles driven in the
    `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and are
    reimbursed \$1.00 per mile they reported. An expense for 100 miles
    would equal a reimbursement of \$100.00.
  - **Per Diem**: If employees receive a daily flat rate of \$125.00
    when traveling, set the `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to
    [125.00]{.title-ref}. An expense for three days of per diem costs
    (meals, incidentals, taxi fare, etc.) would equal a reimbursement of
    \$375.00.
  :::

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  The `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is always visible
  on the expense category form, but the `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} field is *only* visible if the
  `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is selected under the
  `Re-Invoice Expenses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section.
  Otherwise, the `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field
  is hidden.
  ::::

- `Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a short
  reference for the expense, such as [FOOD]{.title-ref} or
  [TRAVEL]{.title-ref}. This reference is used when
  `emailing expenses <expenses/email_expense>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}.

- `Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the category the expense falls under. It is recommended
  to use the default category [All / Expenses]{.title-ref}, but another
  category can be selected if the accounting department requires it.

- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If in a multi-company
  database, select the company the expense category applies to. If the
  expense category applies to *all* companies, leave this field blank.

- `Guideline`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter some rules or
  important information for the expense category. This is visible in the
  `Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column on the
  `Expense Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard.

  ::: example
  An expense category for expenses related to working from home may have
  a `Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of [WFH]{.title-ref}, and
  the `Guideline`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} may say [Monitors,
  Chairs, & Other Home Working Costs]{.title-ref}.
  :::

- `Expense Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If using the
  Odoo **Accounting** app, select the `CoA (Chart of
  Accounts)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} the expense should be logged
  on.

  :::: important
  ::: title
  Important
  :::

  Check with the accounting department to determine the correct account
  to reference in this field as it affects various reports.
  ::::

- `Purchase Taxes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
  `Sales Taxes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the default
  taxes that are applied when purchasing or selling this product, if
  applicable.

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  The `Sales Taxes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is **only**
  visible if the **Sales** app is installed, and either the
  `At cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
  `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} options are selected
  in the `invoicing section <expenses/invoicing>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}.
  ::::

  :::: tip
  ::: title
  Tip
  :::

  It is considered good practice to use a tax that is configured with
  `Tax Included in Price
  <taxes/included-in-price>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}. Taxes are
  automatically configured if these are set.
  ::::

![A new expense category for tools.](expense_categories/new-expense-category.png)

### Invoicing section {#expenses/invoicing}

If the **Sales** app is installed, an invoicing section is visible. This
section allows the expense to be reinvoiced to customers on sales
orders.

If the expense **cannot** be reinvoiced, enable the
`No`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option. If the expense category
**can** be reinvoiced, enable either of these options:

- `At cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this option to
  have the expense item reinvoiced at the price set in the
  `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.
- `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this option
  to have the expense item reinvoiced at the sales price. When enabled,
  a `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field appears
  beneath the `Product Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.
  Enter the sales price in the new field.

::: example
A heating and cooling company offers at-home repairs on the furnaces and
central air units it sells. Their technicians are sub-contracted, and
use their own vans, tools, and parts.

As part of their contracts, technicians are reimbursed for their travel.
They receive \$1.00 for every mile they drive. Additionally, the
customer must pay for the travel as part of their service contract. The
customer pays \$1.50 for every mile the technician drives to their
location.

To configure this expense, the `Sales Price`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} is set to [1.50]{.title-ref} and the
`Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to [1.00]{.title-ref}.

![An expense category to reinvoice customers and pay technicians.](expense_categories/reimbursement-category.png)
:::




--- SOURCE: finance/expenses/expenses_analysis.md ---

# Expenses analysis

It is important for companies to track expenses so they have an
understanding of their expenses and can identify trends. Expense
reporting allows for detailed information, such as which expense
categories are reimbursed the most, which employees incur the most
expenses, and if there are any periods of time that tend to incur more
expenses than others.

## View expense analysis report

To view the default *Expenses Analysis* report, navigate to
`Expenses app -->
Reporting --> Expenses Analysis`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. The `Expenses Analysis`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} report displays all expenses for the current year, in a
stacked bar chart, grouped by month.

![The default stacked bar chart for annual expenses, grouped by month.](expenses_analysis/default-report.png)

## View expenses by employee

It is possible to view the data so that the total cost of expenses *by
employee* is visible. To view the report in this way, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Reporting --> Expenses
Analysis`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Next, click the
`oi-view-pivot`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(Pivot)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon to view the data in a
pivot table.

This presents the data with the *employees* populating the rows, and the
*total monthly expenses* populate the columns. Next, click
`fa-minus-square-o`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at the top of the monthly
columns to hide the individual monthly totals, and present only the
*total* amount for the year.

To present the data in either ascending or descending total, click the
`Total In Currency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} box, and the
information is organized first in ascending order, starting with the
smallest amount. Click `Total In Currency`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} again to reverse the order, and present the highest
amount first.

::: example
In this example it can be determined that `Mike Smith`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} has the highest amount of expenses, totaling
`4,216.44`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This is almost seven
times higher than `Ronnie
Hart`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, who has the second highest
expenses, with a total of `644.74`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![A pivot table with the information shown by employee, in descending order.](expenses_analysis/by-employee.png)
:::

## View expenses by category

It is possible to view the data so that the total cost of expenses *by
category* is visible. To view the report in this way, navigate to
`Expenses app --> Reporting --> Expenses
Analysis`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Next, click the
`oi-view-pivot`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(Pivot)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon to view the data in a
pivot table.

This presents the data with the *employees* populating the rows, and the
*total monthly expenses* populate the columns. Next, click
`fa-minus-square-o`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at the top of the employees
column. Click `fa-plus-square`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} that appears in place of
`fa-minus-square-o`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, revealing a drop-down menu
of options. Click `Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
expense categories now populate the rows.

Next, click `fa-minus-square-o`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at the top of the months
column to hide the individual months, and only show the annual total for
each category.

To present the data in either ascending or descending total, click the
`Total In Currency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} box, and the
information is organized first in ascending order, starting with the
smallest amount. Click `Total In Currency`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} again to reverse the order, and present the highest
amount first.

::: example
In this example, it can be determined that the company spent the most on
travel expenses, with the expense category
`[TRANS & ACC] Travel & Accommodation`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} incurring `2,940.00`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
of expenses for the year. The company reimbursed mileage the least, with
only `229.69`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in
`[MIL] Mileage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} expenses.

![A pivot table with the information shown by catrgory in descending order.](expenses_analysis/by-category.png)
:::




--- SOURCE: finance/expenses/log_expenses.md ---

# Log expenses

Before expenses can be reimbursed, each individual expense needs to be
