# United Arab Emirates

## Configuration

`Install <general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} the following
modules to get all the features of the **United Arab Emirates**
**Payroll** localization:

  Name                                                                                  Technical name                             Description
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------ ----------------------------------------------------------
  `United Arab Emirates - Payroll`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}                   [l10n_ae_hr_payroll]{.title-ref}           Includes all rules, calculations, and salary structures.
  `United Arab Emirates - Payroll with Accounting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}   [l10n_ae_hr_payroll_account]{.title-ref}   Includes all accounts related to the payroll module.

::: seealso
`United Arab Emirates fiscal localization documentation
<../../../finance/fiscal_localizations/united_arab_emirates>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## Employees

First, configure the
`employee general information <../../employees/new_employee>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} and then configure the following fields under the
`Private Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab:

- `Nationality (Country)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
  nationality affects an employee\'s payslips, whether they are
  nationals or expats.
- `Identification Number`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Used to
  extract the `WPS report
  <payroll/l10n_ae/wps-reports>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
- `Bank Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Used to extract the
  `WPS report <payroll/l10n_ae/wps-reports>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"} and generate payments for those employees.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `Nationality (Country)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field
needs to be set even if the employee is a
`UAE (United Arab Emirates)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} national
since there is a different type of handling if they are citizens of a
`GCC (Gulf Cooperation Council)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} country.
::::

## Contracts

Once the employee form has been created, ensure the
`contract <../contracts>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} is enabled by
clicking on the `fa-book`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Contracts`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart button, or going to
`Employees --> Contracts`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

The following contractual information related to employees working in
the United Arab Emirates are found under the
`Salary Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab:

- `Wage Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: select
  `Fixed Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for Full-time or
  Part-time employees, or `Hourly Wage`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} for employees who are paid hourly.
- `Scheduled Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the frequency of
  payslip issuance.
- `Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: `Monthly`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} or `Hourly`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
  depending on the `Wage
  Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- `Housing Allowance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
- `Transportation Allowance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
- `Other Allowance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The allowance values set on the contract are used on the payslip lines
as allowances.
::::

- `Number of Leave Days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Used to
  specify the number of annual leave days that an employee deserves in a
  particular year. Regardless of the actual number of leaves that the
  employee gets (extra leave days for some internal company reasons),
  the final calculation of the end of service and unpaid leaves is
  dependent on the number set on this field.

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  The `Number of Leave Days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} affects
  the calculation for unpaid leave provisions.
  ::::

- `Is DEWS Applied`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: DIFC Employee
  Workplace Savings (DEWS), if the employee is a
  `UAE (United Arab Emirates)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} national
  and has
  `DEWS (Daman Investments End of Service Programme)`{.interpreted-text
  role="abbr"} applied, tick this checkbox.

- `Computed Based On Daily Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  Defines the way that the end of service is calculated:

  - Do not tick this checkbox if the standard calculation is to be used.
    This computes the compensation amount by dividing the monthly salary
    by **30** and then multiplying it by **21**.
  - Tick this checkbox and directly set the actual
    `Daily Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} so that it is used
    in the end of service calculation.
  - Tick this checkbox and directly set the actual
    `Daily Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} so that it is used
    in the end of service calculation.

## Salary structures and salary rules

### Other input rules

The following are the different allowances that can be defined directly
on the `payslip form
<../payslips>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} to allow for the values
that are set against these inputs to affect the
`WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
calculations as monthly variable salaries for the specific employee that
they are linked to.

Rules that are related to the
`WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} setup,
are linked to other input types, and whenever they are used, their
values are reflected on the
`WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} as
monthly variable salary for that specific employee.

  ---------------------------------------------- -------------------------------
  **Type**                                       **Code**

  `Conveyance Allowance`{.interpreted-text       [CONVALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Housing Allowance`{.interpreted-text          [HOUALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Medical Allowance`{.interpreted-text          [MEDALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Annual Passage Allowance`{.interpreted-text   [ANNUALPASSALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Overtime Allowance`{.interpreted-text         [OVERTIMEALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Other Allowance`{.interpreted-text            [OTALLOW]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               

  `Leave Encashment`{.interpreted-text           [LEAVEENCASH]{.title-ref}
  role="guilabel"}                               
  ---------------------------------------------- -------------------------------

### End of service (EOS)

End of service (EOS) provides the calculation for the allowance that the
employee gets at the end of their service. It is triggered when the
employee\'s departure reason is set by archiving the employee\'s record.

There are several different calculations depending on the scenario:

1.  *The Employee spent less than a year in the company*: The employee
    does not get any `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text
    role="abbr"} allowance since they are not eligible for it (they are
    eligible once they complete their first year in the company).

2.  *The Employee spent more than a year and less than 5 years in the
    company*: The employee is eligible for an equivalent of **21** days
    of salary for each year they spent on the company.

    :::: note
    ::: title
    Note
    :::

    There are two ways for calculating the daily wage that gets paid for
    the employee against the 21 days of the
    `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}: Either by the
    default way of dividing the monthly basic wage by 30. Or, it can be
    manually input on the contract of the employee under the *Daily
    Salary* field.
    ::::

3.  *The Employee spent more than 5 years in the company*: The employee
    is eligible for an equivalent of **30** days of salary for each year
    they spent on the company. In this case, if the default method is
    used, then the employee gets paid an equivalent of 1 month of
    salary, and the set *Daily Salary* field, they will get the amount
    for the day multiplied by 30.

    :::: note
    ::: title
    Note
    :::

    There are two payslips printout formats, one for normal salaries and
    one for end of service payslips, it is based on the employee being
    archived and having a departure reason or not.
    ::::

### End of service provision (EOS Provision)

The `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} provision
provides the calculation for the end-of-service provision amount that
the company puts aside every month to count for the
`EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} that will be paid
to them as an `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
allowance.

Unlike the `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, the
provision is part of the employee\'s payslip from the start of their
contract.

Just like the `EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, the
provision has two calculations depending on the period spent by the
employee in the company:

- Less than 5 years:
  $\frac{\text{Monthly Wage}}{30}\times{\frac{21}{12}}$

- More than 5 years:
  $\frac{\text{Monthly Wage}}{30}\times{\frac{30}{12}}$

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  This rule is not shown to the employee on the payslip printout and it
  does not affect their net payable, it is only for internal use by the
  company.
  ::::

### Annual leave provisions

Annual leave provisions are used for calculating the annual leave
provision accumulated each month, just like the
`EOS (End Of Service)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} provision, it does
not affect the total amount paid to the employee, it is for internal use
by the company.

It is calculated by dividing the employee\'s total salary (Total Salary
= Wage + Allowances) by **30** to get the daily salary. The daily salary
is then multiplied by the eligible leave days and divided by **12** to
determine the monthly provision amount.

[$$\text{Monthly Leave Provision} = \frac{\text{Total Salary} \times \text{Number of Leave Days}}{30}
\div 12$$]{.overflow-scroll}

### Social insurance contributions

Social insurance contributions calculate the *social insurance*, which
is only available to `UAE (United Arab Emirates)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} nationals.

The company contributes **15%** of the total monthly salary for the
employee if the company is in **Abu Dhabi** and **12.5%** if the company
is in **another Emirate**.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The total monthly salary for the employee = \[basic + all allowances set
on the contract\].
::::

On the other hand, the employee contributes **5%** of their total
monthly salary and that amount gets deducted from the payslip amount.

### Annual remaining leave balance rules

Annual remaining leave balance rules are used for calculating the amount
to be paid to or taken from the employee based on the number of leave
days deserved by the employee during the current year.

The annual leave
`time off type <time_off/time-off-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
is specified using the `Is
Annual Leave`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} checkbox.

If enabled, the rule calculates the amount of leave days deserved by the
employee up to the current date and subtracts the number of annual leave
days taken, and if the result is positive, this means that the employee
should be compensated for remaining amount and if negative this means
that the employee is liable to the company for the difference.

### Sick leave rules

Sick leave rules provide the calculation for cases where the employee is
on sick leave and decides how the payslip should be affected.

There are **3 cases** for the employee to have:

1.  **Fully paid sick leave:** The employee can upload a sick leave
    certificate (SLI). Employees are eligible for **15 days** of this
    type of leave per calendar year.

    :::: tip
    ::: title
    Tip
    :::

    The SLI is not mandatory in Odoo but can be done from the setup of
    the `time off types
    <time_off/time-off-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
    ::::

2.  **50% paid sick leave:** Same as the fully paid one, but the
    employees are eligible for **30 days** from this leave type. These
    30 days are counted after the first **15** fully paid days.

3.  **0% paid sick leave:** Same as the fully paid one, but the
    employees are eligible for **45 days** from this leave type. These
    **45 days** are counted after the first **15/30** fully/half-paid
    days.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

As per the labor law of the United Arab Emirates, the 15, 30, 45 days
are not specified as working days or calendar days so this point will
rely on the company policy.
::::

The amount paid for the employee per sick leave day is counted as
follows:

[$$\frac{\text{Number of Leave Days} \times \text{Gross Per Month}}{30} \times \text{Percentage}$$]{.overflow-scroll}

Where the gross per month is the basic + all other allowances set on the
employee\'s contract.

### Daman investments end of service programme (DEWS)

`DEWS (Daman Investments End of Service Programme)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} allows for calculating the
`DEWS (Daman Investments End of Service Programme)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} amounts for the employees who are eligible for it and would
like to be registered on it under their current contract with the
company.

It is calculated based on the number of years that employees have spent
in the company:

- **Less than 5 years:** 5.83% is deducted from the employee\'s
  **BASIC** salary towards the DEWS.
- **More than 5 years:** 8.33% of The employee\'s **BASIC** is deducted
  from the total payable for that employee.

### Unpaid leaves

Unpaid leaves allows for calculating the amount to be deducted when an
employee takes an unpaid leave. It is calculated by the following
equation:

[$$\frac{\text{Total Number of Unpaid Leave Days} \times \text{Gross Per Month}}{30}$$]{.overflow-scroll}

Where the gross per month is the basic + all other allowances set on the
employee\'s contract.

### Out of contract days

The out of contract days rule provides a calculation for the days
before/after the contract period that overlaps with the contract of days
on the employee\'s payslips.

::: example
Payslips are generated for the period of 1st-30th of September but the
contract expires on the 21st, in this case, there are 7 days flagged as
out of contract.
:::

It is calculated by the following equation:

[$$\frac{\text{Total Number of Unpaid Leave Days} \times \text{Gross Per Month}}{\text{Number of Days in Current Month}}$$]{.overflow-scroll}

### Manual deductions

Manual deductions allows the user to add manual deductions to be applied
to employees per payslip.

The amount to be deducted and the description of the deduction is to be
set directly on the payslip manually as other inputs.

### Net salary

Net salary showcases the net amount that the employee will get based on
the payslip.

It is calculated by adding basic to all allowances and deducting all
deductions from it.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

The approach taken for the rules above is to first get the full amounts
for all static amounts that are set on the contract and then deduct the
amounts that should be deducted such as unpaid leaves, sick leaves,
manual deductions, commission, etc.
::::

## Generating accounting entries from payslips

The accounts are linked to each payroll rule as a debit or credit so
that when a draft entry is generated from a payslip, the amounts are
reflected on the accounts accordingly.

The accounts need to be set in a way that would make the end-result
entry balanced, otherwise a warning is raised if it is not balanced and
it will not generate the entry.

After reviewing the payslips and making sure that all the amounts are
correct, generate a draft entry, either one entry for all employees or
an entry per employee depending on the setup done on the settings.

::: example
Debit and credit accounts set up for the basic and allowance rules.

![Accounting setup for the rules.](united_arab_emirates/accounting-setup-for-rules.png)
:::

## Pay employees

After a batch or a payslip\'s journal entry has been posted, the company
can proceed to pay their employees.

In the batch itself or on the payslip, by clicking on the pay button, a
payment is created and linked to the posted entry for the payslip. The
same can be done for batch payslips if one payment is done from a
single/multiple payment bank/cash journal.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Once the payslip is generated, the employee will be able to access the
slips from their portal users. They will automatically receive an email
mentioning that the payslips are now available to be viewed on their
portal view.
::::

## Payslip printouts

Two printout formats can be extracted from the payslip, it depends on
the type of the payslip either a *Monthly* payslip or an *End of
Service* Payslip. It is triggered if the employee for the payslip is
generated is archived during that month.

## Instant Pay structure

This structure is used when off-cycle payslips are required to make
payments to employees for special situations, such as one-time or
advance salaries. Examples of one-time payments include:

- Commissions
- Bonuses
- Allowances

## Salary Advances

Employees may request a portion of their salary before the end of the
pay cycle. In such cases, the payroll officer can issue a salary advance
using the following steps:

1.  Create an off-cycle payslip using the United Arab Emirates: Instant
    Pay structure.
2.  Add another input of type Salary Advance and specify the amount to
    be paid to the employee.
3.  Confirm the payslip and process the payment.

In the next cycle, when a payslip is generated for the employee using
the [United Arab Emirates: Regular Pay]{.title-ref} structure, another
input type, [Advance Recovery]{.title-ref} is automatically added for
the same amount that was previously paid.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If the employee and payroll officer agree to recover the advance over
two consecutive cycles, the payroll officer can adjust the Advance
Recovery amount on the first payslip. The remaining balance is
automatically added to the following cycle.
::::

## Wages protection system (WPS) reports {#payroll/l10n_ae/wps-reports}

The `WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is a
report that needs to be submitted by the company to prove that they paid
their employees the right amounts on the right dates. It can either be
generated per payslip or batch.

The following steps need to be followed before generating the report:

1.  Go to `Payroll --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
    role="menuselection"} and under the `UAE
    Payroll WPS Settings`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section,
    configure the following:

    - `Employer Unique ID`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Set a
      unique identifier for the company to be used in the
      `WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
      report.

    - `Salaries Bank Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select
      a bank account or start typing to `Create
      and edit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} a new bank account.

      :::: important
      ::: title
      Important
      :::

      When setting the `Salaries Bank Account`{.interpreted-text
      role="guilabel"} make sure to complete the following:

      - `Account Holder`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: set as the
        company.
      - `Account Number`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: has to be a
        valid IBAN.
      - `Bank`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: has to have the
        `UAE Routing Code Agent ID`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
        set.
      - `Send Money`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: should be
        enabled and set to `Trusted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
      ::::

2.  Set the unique identifier on all of the employees who are a part of
    the target of the batch/payslip.

    The `Identification No`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field can
    be found on the employee\'s page under the
    `Private Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab.

Once the initial setup is done, the
`WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} can be
generated either for one payslip or for a batch as follows:

1.  Generate the payslip one by one or as a batch.
2.  Post the draft entity related to the payslips.
3.  Create the payment report and set the
    `Export Format`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to
    `UAE WPS`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The report comes in a `.sif`{.interpreted-text role="file"} format as
per the governmental requirements, so either use software that can open
`.sif`{.interpreted-text role="file"} files or convert it to another
format (`.xslx`{.interpreted-text role="file"}) to be able to review it.
::::

The resulting file consists of the following:

1.  **Employee Detail Record** (**EDR**): includes details of the
    employees on the batch. There should be one
    `EDR (Employee Detail Record)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} record
    per employee.
2.  **Employee Variable Pay** (**EVP**): includes the details of the
    variable salary the employee got on that payslip. If the employee
    has any. The variable amounts are calculated from when other inputs
    are used that are linked to the salary rules
    (`Payroll --> Configuration
    --> Rules`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}).
3.  **Salary Control Record** (**SCR**): There should only be one
    `SCR (Salary Control Record)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} per
    `WPS (Wages Protection System)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} file
    as it indicates the employer details and the totals for the
    payslips.




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/payroll_localizations/united_states.md ---

# United States

The U.S. payroll localization covers salary computations for employees,
including both employee and employer payroll taxes. It accounts for
federal and state regulations.

The states included in this localization are:

- California (CA)
- New York (NY)
- Texas (TX)
- Florida (FL)
- Colorado (CO)
- Alabama (AL)
- Washington (WA)
- Nevada (NV)
- Vermont (VT)
- Illinois (IL)
- Virginia (VA)
- Washington, D.C (DC)
- Arizona (AZ)
- Idaho (ID)
- Oregon (OR)
- North Carolina (NC)

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Federal taxes (Income,
`FICA (Federal Insurance Contributions Act)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, and Unemployment) for both employees and employers are
covered by default in the Odoo U.S. Payroll localization. Additional
states will be added over time, so check back for updates.
::::

Before configuring the United States localization, refer to the general
`payroll
<../../payroll>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} documentation, which
includes the basic information for all localizations, as well as all
universal settings and fields.

## Apps & modules {#payroll/usa_apps}

`Install <general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} the following
modules to get all the features of the United States payroll
localization:

+-------------------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------+--------------------------+--------------------+
| Name                                                        | Technical name                           | Dependencies             | Description        |
+=============================================================+==========================================+==========================+====================+
| `United States - Payroll`{.interpreted-text                 | [l10n_us_hr_payroll]{.title-ref}         | - hr_payroll             | Provides U.S.      |
| role="guilabel"}                                            |                                          | - hr_contract_reports    | payroll basics,    |
|                                                             |                                          | - hr_work_entry_holidays | including employee |
|                                                             |                                          | - hr_payroll_holidays    | tax details,       |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | salary structures  |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | (Basic/Gross/Net), |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | tax rules, and     |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | W-2/3PA reporting. |
+-------------------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------+--------------------------+--------------------+
| `United States - Payroll with Accounting`{.interpreted-text | [l10n_us_hr_payroll_account]{.title-ref} | - hr_payroll_account     | Links payroll and  |
| role="guilabel"}                                            |                                          | - l10n_us                | accounting by      |
|                                                             |                                          | - l10n_us_hr_payroll     | creating journal   |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | entries (per       |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | payslip if needed) |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | to record payroll  |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | in the company\'s  |
|                                                             |                                          |                          | books.             |
+-------------------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------+--------------------------+--------------------+

::: seealso
`Configure the United States fiscal localization
<../../../finance/fiscal_localizations/united_states>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

## General configurations

First, the company must be configured. Navigate to
`Settings app --> Users &
Companies --> Companies`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. From
the list, select the desired company, and configure the following
fields:

- `Company Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the business
  name in this field.

- `Address`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Complete the full
  address, including the `City`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `State`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Zip Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
  `Country`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

  :::: important
  ::: title
  Important
  :::

  The state selected in the company\'s address is associated as the
  *work address* by default for the employee, and the one used to
  calculate payroll taxes.
  ::::

- `Tax ID`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the company\'s
  `EIN (Employer Identification Number)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

- `Company ID`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} : Enter the
  business\'s state ID number.

- `Currency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: By default,
  `USD (US Dollars)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is selected. If not,
  select `USD`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} from the drop-down
  menu.

- `Phone`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the company phone
  number.

- `Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the email used for
  general contact information.

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

Ensure the information is accurate, as it is used when creating W-2s.
::::

## Employees

Every employee being paid must have their employee profiles configured
for the United States payroll localization. Additional fields are
present after configuring the database for the United States.

To update an employee form, open the `Employees`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} app and click on the desired employee record. On
the employee form, configure the required fields in the related tabs.

### Work tab

Enter the `Work Address`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for the
employee in the `Location`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section of
the `Work`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

The state selected in this address determines which salary rules Odoo
applies when calculating taxes.
::::

### Personal tab

Ensure the employee has a minimum of one
`trusted bank account <employees/private-contact>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} listed in the `Bank Accounts`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field in the `Private Contact`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section.

These accounts are used to pay the employee, via an automation through a
NACHA payment file. Payroll **cannot** be processed for employees
without a *trusted* `bank account
<employees/private-contact>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}. If no
trusted bank account is set, a warning appears on the **Payroll**
dashboard and an error occurs when attempting to run payroll.

Ensure there is a valid `SSN No`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
entered in the `Citizenship`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section
. The last four digits of the
`SSN (Social Security Number)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} number
appears on the employee\'s payslips.

![Where bank account information is located on the employee profile.](united_states/bank.png)

### Payroll tab

#### Contract overview section

This section holds information that drives salary calculations. Ensure
the following fields are configured:

- `Contract`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The Validity of the
  compensation conditions can be updated depending on the needs.

- `Wage Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select how the
  employee is paid.

  - Select `Fixed Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for salaried
    employees who receive the same amount each pay period.
  - Select `Hourly Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for
    employees paid based on hours worked.

  :::: tip
  ::: title
  Tip
  :::

  Set a default `Wage Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the
  salary `Structure Type
  <payroll/structure-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} to configure
  employees in bulk. If needed, the default can be overridden on
  individual employee records if exceptions are needed.
  ::::

- `Contract Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Determines how the
  employee is paid and classified, such as
  `Salary-exempt`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Salary-nonexempt`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Hourly`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

  :::: important
  ::: title
  Important
  :::

  This field is visible on payslips. Some states require payslips to
  state if the employee is exempt or non-exempt from overtime. Ensure
  the selection follows the state laws.
  ::::

- `Pay Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select
  `United States: Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for this
  field. This defines when the employee is paid, their default working
  schedule, and the work entry type it applies to.

![The contract overview section of the employee form of the payroll tab.](united_states/payroll-overview.png)

#### Schedule section

- `Work Entry Source`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Defines how
  `work entries <../work_entries>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} are
  generated for payroll during the specified pay period. The options
  are:
  - `Working Schedule`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Based on the
    employee\'s assigned `working schedule
    <employees/schedule>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} (e.g., 40 hours
    per week).
  - `Attendances`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Based on
    `approved checked-in hours
    <../../attendances/management>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} in the
    **Attendances** app.
  - `Planning`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Based on
    `scheduled shifts <planning/shifts>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
    in the **Planning** app.
- `Extra Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick the checkbox to
  allow the **Attendances** app to add any extra work entries logged by
  the employee.
- `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select the default work schedule. This is particularly
  important for employees available to receive overtime pay (typically
  hourly employees, not salaried).

#### W-2 form section

A W-2 is an annual tax form that reports an employee\'s wages, taxes,
and benefits. Employees use it to file their tax returns. The options
below correspond to checkboxes in *box 13* of the W-2 form. Select any
that apply to the employee.

- `Statutory Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this box
  if the employee is exempt from income tax, but subject to
  `FICA (Federal Insurance Contributions Act)`{.interpreted-text
  role="abbr"} taxes.
- `Retirement Plan`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this box if
  the employee is an active contributor to an employer-sponsored
  retirement plan.
- `Third-Party Sick Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this
  box if the employee is covered under a plan where sick pay benefits
  may be provided by a third party (e.g., an insurance company) during
  the year.

#### W-4 form section

A W-4 is an `IRS (Internal Revenue Services)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} form that determines an employee\'s federal tax
withholding, which the employer remits directly to the
`IRS (Internal Revenue Services)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

Configure any relevant fields for the employee in this section.

#### State filing section

An employee\'s marital status impacts their payroll taxes. Configure the
following fields regarding their status and withholdings.

- `Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down menu,
  select the employee\'s *federal* filing status. The options are
  `Single`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Married/RDP filing jointly`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Married/RDP
  filing separately`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Head of household`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
  `Qualifying surviving spouse/RDP
  with child`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This typically comes
  from the employee\'s W-4 form.

- `Tax Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the employee\'s *state* filing status, if applicable.

  :::: tip
  ::: title
  Tip
  :::

  The federal and state statuses do **not** need to match.
  ::::

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  As of 2025, these states do **not** collect state income tax: Alaska,
  Florida, Nevada, New Hampshire, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas,
  Washington, and Wyoming. If a payroll localization exists for these
  states, there are **no** corresponding state options in the `Tax
  Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field. Leave it blank.
  ::::

- `Withholding Allowance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
  total annual amount to be withheld from the employee\'s pay for the
  year, for state taxes. Only fill this out if the employee lives in a
  state with state income tax.

- `Extra Withholding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
  total *extra* annual amount (not including the
  `Withholding Allowance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} amount) to
  be withheld from the employee\'s pay for the year, for state taxes, if
  the employee lives in a state with state income tax.

![The state filing section of the employee form, filled out.](united_states/state-filing.png)

#### Common benefits

The following sections of benefits are considered common ones offered by
US employers. This information needs to be populated with the
information selected by the employee.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The benefits listed in this section are considered the most commonly
offered by companies. If other employee benefits exist that require
regular paycheck deductions, they can be added as *inputs*.
::::

##### Pre-tax deductions

Pre-tax benefits lower the employee\'s gross wage, which decreases the
base amount for tax calculations. These are displayed at the beginning
of the payslip before the gross wage is stipulated.

###### Retirement plans section

This section is where the employee and employer 401(k) contributions are
configured. Fill out the following fields:

- `401(k)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the amount of money
  taken out of the employee\'s payslip each pay period. This can be
  entered either as a percentage (%) of the payslip amount, or a
  specific dollar amount per payslip (\$/slip).
- `Matching Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
  matching amount the employer contributes to the employee\'s 401(k), as
  compared to the employee\'s contributions. This field can also be
  configured as either a percentage (%) of the employee\'s contribution,
  or a specific dollar amount (\$/slip).
- `Matching Yearly Cap`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If there is
  a limit to the employer\'s contribution, enter it as a percentage of
  the employee\'s annual salary.

::: example
A company allows employees to contribute to a 401(k) retirement plan,
and matches 50% of the employee\'s contributions, up to \$5,000 USD a
year. The employee earns \$50,000 USD a year, and contributes 20% of
their pay to their 401(k), which is \$10,000 USD.

To configure this, enter [20.00]{.title-ref} in the
`401(k)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, [50.00]{.title-ref}
in the `Matching Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and
[20.00]{.title-ref} in the `Matching Yearly Cap`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field.

![An employee\'s retirement configurations.](united_states/retirement.png)
:::

###### Health benefits section

This section is where the employee\'s health contributions are
configured. Populate each of the fields with the corresponding amount
deducted from *each paycheck* for the employee.

![The health benefits section for an employee, filled out with payslip deductions.](united_states/health.png)

###### Other benefits section

This section currently only houses a `Commuter`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} benefit field. Enter the amount being deducted per
paycheck, for applicable commuter benefits.

##### Post-tax deductions section

These types of benefits count as deductions *after* taxes are
calculated. They appear towards the end of the payslip before the net
amount is displayed. Currently, only one field, `ROTH
401(k)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} appears in this section.
Enter either a percentage (%) of the payslip amount, or a specific
dollar amount per payslip (\$/slip) being deducted from the employee\'s
pay, and deposited into a ROTH 401(k) account.

## Payroll configuration

Several sections within the **Payroll** app installs a Salary Structure,
Structure Type, Rules, and Parameters specific to the United States.

### Salary structures & structure types

When the **l10n_us_hr_payroll** module is
`installed <payroll/usa_apps>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, a new
`Salary Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} gets installed,
`United States: Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This
structure includes one `Structure Type`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `United States: Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

The `Salary Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} contains all
the individual `salary rules <payroll/usa_apps>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} that informs the **Payroll** app how to calculate employee
payslips.

![The United States salary structure in the salary structures list.](united_states/structure-types.png)

### Salary rules {#payroll/usa_rules}

To view the salary rules that inform the salary structure what to do,
navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Structures`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and expand the `United
States: Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} group to reveal the
`United States: Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
structure type. Click `United States: Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to view the detailed salary rules.

![The top portion of the US salary rules.](united_states/us-rules-top-half.png)

Each rule defines how pay is calculated, taking into account factors
such as commissions, bonuses, taxes, and insurance. The *logic* behind
the `United States: Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
rules is as follows:

- The first four rules listed reflects all sources of income, including
  the basic wage listed on the contract
  (`Basic Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}), plus any
  allowances, such as `Commissions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Tips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
  `Bonuses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

  ![The basic salary rules for the US localization.](united_states/first-rules.png)

- Adding up these inputs is how the gross salary
  (`Gross Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}) is calculated. This
  amount is the base amount used to calculate payroll taxes.

- The next set of rules are the various pre-tax benefits and taxable
  income, such as `Medical`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} insurance
  contributions and `Commuter Benefits`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}. After the employee\'s `Gross Pay`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} is calculated, Odoo deducts all the pre-tax benefits
  listed on the employee\'s contract to determine the employee\'s
  `Taxable Income`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

  ![The pre-tax rules for the US localization.](united_states/pre-tax.png)

- Next, all the various tax rules are listed where both federal and
  state payroll withholdings are outlined. First, federal tax rules are
  listed, then any state rules (if any) are listed.

  ![The federal tax rules for the US localization.](united_states/irs.png)

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  The rule for federal withholdings for [Worker\'s
  Compensation]{.title-ref} appears *after* several state-specific
  withholdings are listed, and does **not** appear in the above image,
  but are listed in the rules.
  ::::

- The last rules listed are the post-tax employee deductions.

  ![The post-tax rules for the US localization.](united_states/post-tax.png)

- The `Other Inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab contains
  anything else affecting payroll. This includes items to be added to
  the payslip, such as `Tips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
  other deductions, such as `Child
  Support`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

  ![The other inputs for the US localization.](united_states/other-inputs.png)

- The employee\'s net salary is the amount the employee receives from
  the employer. The formula to calculate the net salary is:

  $$\text{Gross Salary} + \text{Allowances} - \text{Payroll Taxes} - \text{General Deductions}$$

- Additionally, an extra section exists in payroll calculation for the
  US called [Employer Deductions]{.title-ref}, and it breaks down the
  payments the employer must make as their portion of payroll taxes.

  ![The employer deduction rules for the US localization.](united_states/employer-deductions.png)

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  The rule for employer deductions for [Worker\'s
  Compensation]{.title-ref} appears *after* several state-specific
  employer deductions are listed, and does **not** appear in the above
  image, but are listed in the rules.
  ::::

### Rule parameters

Some calculations require specific rates associated with them, or wage
caps. *Rules Parameters* are capable of listing a value, either a
percentage or a fixed amount, to reference in the salary rules.

::: example
The wage base for Social Security tax calculations has a cap for 2025,
accounted for in the [US: FICA OASDI Cap]{.title-ref} parameter.
:::

Most rules pull information stored in the parameters module to get the
rate of the rule (a percentage) and the cap (a dollar amount).

To view rule parameters, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Rule
Parameters`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Here, all rule
parameters are displayed with their linked
`Salary Rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, which can be
accessed. Review the parameters associated with a rule by looking for
the `Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of the rule, and make any
edits as needed.

::: example
The Unemployment tax of a company is different from the one added by
default in Odoo. To update this, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Rule Parameters`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, then, filter the results by
`FUTA (Federal Unemployment Tax Act)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, or
the name of the state that needs editing, and edit the corresponding
rate from the list.
:::

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

Odoo adds updated rule parameters for the current calendar year. It is
**not** recommended to edit rule parameters **unless a federal or state
parameter has changed**, and is different from the rule parameters
created by Odoo. Check with all local and national regulations *before*
making any changes to rule parameters.
::::

## Run US payroll

Before running paypoll, the payroll officer must validate employee
`work entries
<../work_entries>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} to confirm pay accuracy
and catch errors. This includes checking that all time off is approved
and any overtime is appropriate.

Work entries sync based on the employee\'s
`contract <../contracts>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} configuration.
Odoo pulls from the assigned working schedule, attendance records,
planning schedule, and approved time off.

Any `discrepencies or conflicts <payroll/conflicts>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} must be resolved, then the work entries can be
`regenerated <payroll/regenerate-work-entries>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

Once everything is correct, draft payslips can be
`created individually <payroll/process>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
or in `groups <../pay_runs>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, referred to
in the **Payroll** app as *Pay Runs*.

![The work entries for a pay run, with some time off entered in the work entries.](united_states/work-entries.png)

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

To cut down on the payroll officer\'s time, it is typical to process
payslips in batches, either by wage type (fixed salary vs hourly), pay
schedule (weekly, bi-weekly, monthly, etc.), department (direct cost vs.
administration), or any other grouping that best suits the company.
::::

The process of running payroll includes different actions that need to
be executed to ensure that the amount withheld from payroll taxes is
correct, the amount that the employee receives as their net salary is
correct, and the computation of hours worked reflects the employee\'s
actual hours worked, among others.

When running a payroll batch, check that the period, company, and
employees included are correct *before* starting to analyze or validate
the data.

Once the payslips are drafted, review them for accuracy. Check the
`Worked Days & Inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, and
ensure the listed worked time is correct, as well as any other inputs.
Add any missing inputs, such as commissions, tips, reimbursements, that
are missing.

Next, check the various totals (gross pay, employee taxes, benefits,
employer taxes, net salaries), then click
`Compute Sheet`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to update the salary
calculations, if there were edits. If everything is correct, click
`Validate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![The worked days tab of a payslip.](united_states/check-payslips.png)

### Accounting check

The accounting process when running payroll has two components:
`creating journal entries
<payroll/journal>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, and
`registering payments <payroll/register>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

#### Journal entry creation {#payroll/journal}

After payslips are confirmed and validated, journal entries are posted
either individually, or in a batch. The journal entry is created first
as a draft.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

It must be decided if journal entries are done individually or in
batches *before* running payroll.
::::

![All payslips in a draft state.](united_states/create-draft-entry.png)

Four accounts from the US `CoA (Chart of Accounts)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} are included with the payroll localization:

- \`611000 Salaries & Wages\`: Records gross salary and the employer\'s
  portion of payroll expenses. Also groups values from rules without
  specific accounts (e.g., company-specific benefits).
- \`230100 Employee Payroll Taxes\`: Withheld taxes from employees,
  which the employer must file and pay. The partner and label columns of
  the journal entry indicate the specific tax.
- \`230200 Employer Payroll Taxes\`: Employer portion of payroll taxes
  to be filed and paid. The partner and label columns of the journal
  entry indicate the specific tax.
- \`230000 Salary Payable\`: Net salary owed to the employee.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `CoA (Chart of Accounts)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
configuration is done by default when a company is located in the US.
The account codes and names can be edited to suit the company\'s needs.
If there is no `CoA (Chart of Accounts)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
account associated with a salary rule (used in a salary structure), Odoo
uses the account [Salary Expenses]{.title-ref} to create the journal
entry, regardless of the nature of the move.
::::

If everything seems correct on the journal entry draft, post the journal
entries.

![Journal entries posted.](united_states/post-entries.png)

### Register Payments {#payroll/register}

After the `journal entries <payroll/journal>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} are validated, Odoo can generate payments.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

To generate payments from payslips,employee\'s **must** have a *trusted*
bank account. If the employee\'s bank account is *not* marked as
[trusted]{.title-ref}, NACHA files **cannot** be generated through Odoo.
::::

Payments can be `Grouped by Partner`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
if there is a partner associated with a salary rule.

![Payslips with a status of paid.](united_states/paid.png)

### Close Payroll

If there are no errors, payroll is completed for the pay period.

## Reports

The US localization contains several reports unique to the US, which
provide tax information for employees, as well as the ability to
integrate with outside organizations such as ADP.

### W2 Report

The *W2 Report* provides a CSV file that allows employees to e-file
their W2 report with third-party software. To access this report,
navigate to `Payroll -> Reporting -> United States
-> W2`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

To create a W2 form, click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
a blank `Create W2 Form`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page loads.
Set the `Start Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`End Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (typically a calendar
year), and select the `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, if
in a multi-company database.

All pay runs for the time period appear in a list view. To add any
missing pay runs, click `Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
at the bottom of the list, and select the missing files.

When done, click the `Generate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button to create a CSV file with a summary of all payroll related
payments made during the specified time period.

![The W2 report screen, with the file to download in the top half.](united_states/w2.png)

### Form 941

The *Form 941* report is meant to inform the government of the amount of
federal income tax,
`FICA (Federal Insurance Contributions Act)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} taxes (Medicare and Social Security) withheld from employee
paychecks. It also reports the employee\'s side of taxes.

To create this report, navigate to
`Payroll -> Reporting -> United States -> Form
941`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Click the
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and a new
`Form 941`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} report page loads.
Configure the information on the top portion of the form, including the
`Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Tax
Year`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Quarter`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `IRS Payment Option`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} (how the money is being sent to the IRS), and
`Deposit Schedule and Tax Liability`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
(how often payments are made to the IRS).

All pay runs for the time period appear in a list view. To add any
missing pay runs, click `Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
at the bottom of the list, and select the missing files.

When done, click `Generate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
report is created as a CSV file, and appears on the
`Form 941`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} report dashboard.
Companies then download and submit this report through a third party for
e-filing.

![The 941 report screen, with the file to download in the top half.](united_states/941.png)

### Form 940

The *Form 940* report details the annual
`FUTA (Federal Unemployment Tax Act)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
withheld for payroll.

To create this report, navigate to
`Payroll -> Reporting -> United States -> Form
940`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Click the
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and a new
`Form 940`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} report page loads.
Configure the information on the top portion of the form, including the
`Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Tax
Year`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Single State Payer`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Multi State Employer`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Paid in Credit
Reduction State`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`IRS Payment Option`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (how the money
is being sent to the IRS).

All pay runs for the time period appear in a list view. To add any
missing pay runs, click `Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
at the bottom of the list, and select the missing files.

When done, click `Generate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
report is created as a CSV file, and appears on the
`Form 940`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} report dashboard.
Companies then download and submit this report through a third party for
e-filing.

![The 940 report screen, with the file to download in the top half.](united_states/940.png)

### Export data to third-party apps

The *ADP Export* report generates a CSV file that can be submitted to
ADP, which then makes payments to the employees.

The CSV file summarizes the employee\'s worked hours during a specified
time period, correlating to their salary or hourly wage. The report is
generated from `work entry <../work_entries>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} *after* any time off is confirmed.

The export format is meant to match with the ADP format. Since companies
can customize their portal and may require some changes, the data is
there to be fed to ADP to run payroll in it.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

To access the ADP Export report, the [United States - Payroll - Export
to ADP]{.title-ref} module **must** be
`installed <general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
::::

# Payroll localizations

*Localizations* are country-specific settings preconfigured in Odoo at
the creation of the database, which account for all taxes, fees, and
allowances for that particular country.

*Payroll localizations* refer to the specific process of adapting
payroll systems, policies, and compliance measures to align with the
specific labor laws, tax regulations, and social security requirements
of a particular country or region.

This ensures that employee salaries, benefits, deductions, and
contributions are processed accurately and in full compliance with local
legal and financial obligations.

Localization also includes integrating country-specific payroll elements
such as benefits, holidays, termination rules, and reporting
requirements, helping businesses avoid legal risks while ensuring
employees receive their correct compensation.

## Install localization package

A country-specific localization module
`must be installed <general/install>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} to
properly configure and process payroll. To install the required module,
first open the **Apps** app.

Clear out the default `fa-filter`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Apps`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} filter, then type the name of
the desired country into the search bar. All available modules for that
country are presented.

::: example
Some countries only have one localization module, while other have
multiple modules. This is typically when other software is neede to
process payroll, and importing and exporting data is required.

For example. when searching for **Payroll** modules for
[Egypt]{.title-ref}, the following modules appear in the search, and
must be installed: [Egypt - Payroll]{.title-ref} and [Egypt - Payroll
with Accounting]{.title-ref}.

Refer to the
`country-specific documentation <payroll_localizations/countries-list>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} for a complete list of the related **Payroll** modules
required for each specific country.
:::

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

To see if any localization modules have been installed on the database,
navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. In the `Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} page, if a localization module was installed, a
`(Country) Localization`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section
appears.
::::

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

It is **not** recommended to alter the localization settings, unless
specifically required.
::::

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Odoo can handle a multi-company configuration. This is generally done
when there is a main company or office location, such as a headquarters,
and there are other offices/branches around the country or globe, that
fall under that main company or headquarters. In Odoo, each company,
including the headquarters, must be set up as their own company/branch
using the multi-company method.

Each individual company can have a different localization setting, since
locations can vary anywhere in the world, where rules and laws differ.

For more information on companies, refer to the
`Companies <../../general/companies>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
documentation, which covers how to set up companies.
::::

## List of countries {#payroll_localizations/countries-list}

Payroll localization modules are available for the countries listed
below.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

New countries are frequently added to this list, as Odoo keeps expanding
and improving existing localizations and related documentation.
::::

- `Australia <payroll_localizations/australia>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}
- `Belgium <payroll_localizations/belgium>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}
- Bangladesh
- `Egypt <payroll_localizations/egypt>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
- `Hong Kong <payroll_localizations/hong_kong>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}
- `India <payroll_localizations/india>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
- Indonesia
- `Jordan <payroll_localizations/jordan>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
- Kenya
- Lithuania
- Luxembourg
- Malaysia
- `Mexico <payroll_localizations/mexico>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
- Morocco
- Netherlands
- Pakistan
- Poland
- Romania
- `Saudi Arabia <payroll_localizations/saudi_arabia>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}
- Slovakia
- Switzerland
- `TÃ¼rkiye <payroll_localizations/turkey>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
- `United Arab Emirates <payroll_localizations/united_arab_emirates>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}
- `United States <payroll_localizations/united_states>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}

::: {.toctree titlesonly=""}

--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/payslips.md ---

# Payslips

*Payslips* are individual records of payment, containing all the details
of how the pay was calculated (hours, deductions, other inputs, etc.),
and generated by payroll officers through the **Payroll** application.
Payslips can be created and processed individually, or multiple payslips
can be processed at one time, in a single batch.

## Create a payslip {#payroll/new-payslip}

A new payslip can be created from either the
`Payslips To Pay <payroll/to-pay>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} page or
the `Employee Payslips <payroll/all-payslips>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} page.

Navigate to `Payroll app --> Payslips`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click either `To Pay`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} or `All Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
Click the `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the
top-left corner, and a blank payslip form loads.

### Payslip form

Fill out the following information on the payslip form:

- `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the employee in this field. This field is **required**.
  Once a selection is made, other fields may auto-populate according to
  the employee record.

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  It is recommended to **only** create payslips for employees that are
  already in the database. If there is no current employee record (and
  therefore no employee contract) it is recommended to create the new
  employee in the **Employees** application *before* creating payslips
  for that employee. Refer to the
  `new employee <../employees/new_employee>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"} documentation for instructions on how to add an employee.
  ::::

- `Contract`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The current contract
  for the selected employee populates this field. This field is
  **required**.

  :::: important
  ::: title
  Important
  :::

  All employees are required to have a contract in order to generate
  payslips. Additionally, *only one* contract can be in the running
  stage for each employee, therefore the current contract populates this
  field, and it is **not** recommended to make changes to this field.
  ::::

- `Batch`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down menu,
  select the payslip batch this new payslip should be added to, if
  applicable.

- `Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The structure linked
  to the employee\'s contract auto-populates this field by default. If
  desired, use the drop-down menu to select a different structure.

- `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The first day to the last
  day of the *current* month auto-populates the
  `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} fields by default. The
  dates can be changed, if desired.

  To change the start date, click on the first date in the
  `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field to reveal a pop-up
  calendar. Navigate to the desired month, and click on the desired day
  to select that specific date.

  Repeat this process to modify the end date for the payslip. These
  fields are **required**.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Typically, after making a selection in the `Employee`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, Odoo auto-populates all other required fields
(besides the `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field), but
**only** if that information is already on that employee\'s form in the
**Employees** app.
::::

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

If modifications to auto-populated fields are made, it is recommended to
check with the accounting department to ensure every entry that affects
the **Accounting** application is correct.
::::

![The top fields for a new payslip all filled out for a February payslip.](payslips/new-payslip.png)

#### Worked days & inputs tab {#payroll/worked-days-inputs}

The `Worked Days & Inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab
details the number of days and hours the employee worked during the
specified `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of time on the top
portion of the payslip form, and is calculated based on the selected
`Contract`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} fields.

The `Worked Days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section is
automatically populated and lists all the individual attendance records
for the time period, including both worked time and any time off taken.

Each individual entry lists the `Type`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Number of
Days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Number of Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the total
`Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Additional records cannot be created for the
`Worked Days & Inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} as it is
auto-populated according to the employee\'s attendance records or
working schedule on their
`employee record <employees/work-info-tab>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

The `Other Inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section is where
additional inputs are listed, such as deductions, reimbursements, and
expenses.

Each individual item lists the `Type`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Count`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. To add a new input, click
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and using the drop-down
menu, select the `Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Next, enter
a brief `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and last,
enter the `Count`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![The fields filled out in the worked days and inputs tab.](payslips/worked-days-tab.png)

#### Salary computation tab

The `Salary Computation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab is where
all the individual salary rules are listed and calculated, including
everything from the employee\'s salary, to all the deductions and
allowances, such as taxes, expenses, benefit contributions, and any
other items associated with the installed
`payroll localization <payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}.

When the payslip is first created, this tab remains blank. Click the
`Compute Sheet`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the
upper-left corner, and the `Salary Computation`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab is populated.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

It is **not** possible to make edits to this tab, as the calculations
are based on other entries on the payslip.
::::

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

The `Compute Sheet`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button does not
disappear from view after it is clicked, so the payslip can be
recalculated at any point prior to
`processing it <payroll/process>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

If any changes need to be made to the
`Worked Days & Inputs <payroll/worked-days-inputs>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} tab, click the `Compute Sheet`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button to recalculate the payslip.
::::

![The fields filled out in the salary computation tab.](payslips/salary-comp-tab.png)

#### Other info tab

The `Other Info`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab houses
information that is required, but not associated with any inputs or
calculations, as the other tabs do.

The `Payslip Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is auto-populated
according to the employee name and the time period the payslip is for.
Make any desired edits to the name in this field. This field is
**required**.

The `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is also
automatically populated according to the employee\'s record, and cannot
be modified.

The end date selected in the `Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field in the top half of the form populates both the
`Close Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Date Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} fields, by default.
The `Close Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is the date the
payment is issued to the employee, while the
`Date Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is the end date the
payslip covers. Modify the dates, if needed.

The `Salary Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is
populated by default, and **cannot** be edited. This is the accounting
journal the paycheck is logged in.

If there are any additional notes or information needed for the payslip,
add them to the `Add an Internal Note...`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field.

![The fields filled out in the other info tab.](payslips/other-info-tab.png)

## Process a payslip {#payroll/process}

When all the necessary information on the payslip is entered, the
payslip can be processed. First, a
`draft of the journal entry <payroll/draft-entry>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} is created, followed by a `payment
report <payroll/payment-report>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, and
finally, the employee is `paid <payroll/pay-employee>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Before processing payslips, it is best practice to check the *Warnings*
section of the **Payroll** app dashboard. Here, all possible issues
concerning payroll appear.

To view the warnings, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Dashboard`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. The
warnings appear in the top-left corner of the dashboard.

![The dashboard view of the Payroll app, with the warnings box visible.](payslips/warnings.png)

Warnings are grouped by type, such as [Employees Without Running
Contracts]{.title-ref} or [Employees Without Bank account
Number]{.title-ref}. Click on a warning to view all entries associated
with that specific issue.

If the warnings are not resolved, at any point in the payslip processing
process, an error may occur. Errors appear in a pop-up window, and
provide details for the error, and how to resolve them.
::::

### Create draft entry {#payroll/draft-entry}

Once everything on the payslip form is correct, click the
`Create Draft Entry`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to create
the payslip. A `Confirmation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window appears, asking `Are you sure
you want to proceed?`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} Click
`OK`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to confirm.

Once the payslip draft is created, the status changes to
`Done`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, a `fa-usd`{.interpreted-text
role="icon"} `Journal Entry (Draft)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
smart button appears at the top, and additional buttons appear in the
top-left corner.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

After creating a draft entry, Odoo considers the payslip as confirmed.
::::

Click the `fa-usd`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Journal Entry (Draft)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart button
to view the detailed accounting journal entry. Click
`Post`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to post the entry. Using the
breadcrumb menu, return to the payslip.

After the journal entry is posted, the smart button at the top changes
to `fa-usd`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Journal Entry (Posted)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Employees cannot be `paid <payroll/pay-employee>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} until the journal entry is posted.
::::

### Create payment report {#payroll/payment-report}

Once the payslip status has changed to `Done`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, a payment report must be created. A payment report is
a document that contains all the necessary information to transfer the
employee\'s earnings from the company\'s bank account to theirs. These
are submitted by the payroll department to the appropriate institution.

Click the `Create Payment Report`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
a pop-up window loads. Using the drop-down menu, select the
`Export Format`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for the payment
report. The two default options available are `NACHA`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} and `CSV`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
`NACHA`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} stands for the
`National Automated
Clearing House Association (NACHA)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, and
this selection creates a compatible ACH file which is sent to the
company\'s bank.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Other options may be available depending on the `payroll localization
<payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} installed in the
database.

If `CSV`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is selected, all other
fields are hidden from view.
::::

Next, select the desired `Bank Journal`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} the paycheck is logged to. Last, using the calendar
selector, set the date the paycheck is issued in the
`Effective Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.

Once the pop-up window is configured, click the
`Generate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and the file
appears on the payslip form, in a new `Payment Report`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field.

### Pay employee {#payroll/pay-employee}

Next, the payment must be sent to the employee. To do this, click the
`Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the upper-left
corner. Doing so reveals a `Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
pop-up form.

All the necessary information is pre-populated on the form according to
the payslip configuration, but modifications can be made, if necessary,
to any of the fields *except* the `Amount`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This is populated according to the payslip
calculations, and **cannot** be modified.

- `Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The accounting journal
  the payslip is logged to.
- `Payment Method`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select how the employee is being paid. The default
  options are:
  - `Manual Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this if
    paying the employee in a method *other* than A
    `Check`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
    `NACHA`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
  - `Check`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this when issuing
    a check directly to the employee.
  - `NACHA`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this if using the
    `National Automated Clearing House Association
    (NACHA)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} to transfer the payment to
    the employee, via direct deposit.
- `Group Payments`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If the employee
  has multiple payslips for the same time period (for example, payroll,
  reimbursement, and commission checks), tick the checkbox to group all
  payments into one payment.
- `Payment Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the calendar
  selector, select the date the employee is to be paid.

Once the pop-up `Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form is
complete, click the `Create Payments`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button, and the payment is processed.

After the payment is processed, and there is confirmation that the
checks have been issued, or the funds have been directly deposited to
the employee\'s bank account, click the `Mark as
paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to mark the payslip as
paid.

![Banking information can be entered in an employee\'s card.](payslips/pay.png)

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

In order for a payslip to be paid, the employee **must** have a bank
account entered in the
`private information tab <employees/private-info>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} of their employee record, *and* the bank account must be
marked as `Trusted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

If there is no bank information, or if the bank is not listed as
`Trusted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, payslips cannot be paid,
and an error appears when the `Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button is clicked. Edit the employee record, and add banking
information, or trust the bank account, as needed.
::::

## Refund a payslip

When refunding a payment, the refund is achieved by creating a payslip
for a negative amount of the original payslip.

::: example
An employee is paid \$5,000.00 USD in a paycheck, in error. When
refunding the payslip, a new payslip is created in the amount of
\$-5,000.00.
:::

If a payment needs to be refunded, navigate to the individual payslip
being refunded, and click the `Refund`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button, located at the top-left of the screen. The
`Refund Payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard loads,
with all refund payslips appearing in a list view.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Since refunds are uncommon, typically only the one payslip being
refunded appears in the list.
::::

By default, the refund payslip has a status of
`Waiting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This refund payslip is
processed
`in the same way a regular payslip is processed <payroll/process>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

## Print a payslip

To print a payslip, click the `Print`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button in the upper-left corner of the individual payslip record. A PDF
file is downloaded, and the payslip appears in the chatter, and the file
is attached to the payslip record.

![The new payslip is emailed to the employee and the email appears in the chatter.](payslips/payslip-chatter.png)

## View all payslips {#payroll/all-payslips}

To view all payslips, regardless of status, go to
`Payroll app --> Payslips --> All
Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. The
`Employee Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page loads,
displaying all payslips, organized by batch, in a default nested list
view.

Click the `â–¶ (right arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} next to
an individual batch name to expand the list, and view all the payslips
in that particular batch, along with all the payslip details.

The number of payslips in the batch is written in parenthesis after the
batch name. The `Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for each
individual payslip appears on the far-right side, indicating one of the
following status options:

- `Draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the payslip is created,
  and there is still time to make edits, since the amounts are not
  calculated.
- `Waiting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the payslip has been
  calculated, and the salary details can be found in the *Salary
  Computation* tab.
- `Done`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the payslip is calculated
  and ready to be paid.
- `Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the employee has been paid.

![View all payslips organized by batches. Click on the arrow to expand each batch.](payslips/all-payslips.png)

Click on an individual payslip to view the details for that payslip on a
separate page. Using the breadcrumb menu, click
