`Employee Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to go back to the
list view of all payslips.

A new payslip can be created from the
`Employee Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page, by clicking
the `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the upper-left
corner. Doing so reveals a separate blank payslip form page. On that
blank payslip form page, enter all the necessary information, as
described in the
`Create a payslip <payroll/new-payslip>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
section.

Payslips can also be exported to an Excel spreadsheet. To export **all**
payslips, click on the `fa-cog`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(gear)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon at the end of the words
`Employee Payslips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the top-left
corner. This reveals a drop-down menu. Click
`fa-upload`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Export All`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to export all payslips
to a spreadsheet.

To export only select payslips, first select the payslips to be exported
from the list. Then, click the checkbox to the left of each individual
payslip to select it. As payslips are selected, a smart button appears
in the top-center of the page, indicating the number of selected
payslips. Then, click the `fa-cog`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Actions`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon in the top-center of
the page, and click `fa-upload`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Export`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Both *To Pay* and *All Payslips* display all the detailed information
for each payslip.
::::

## View payslips to pay {#payroll/to-pay}

To only view the payslips awaiting to be processed, navigate to
`Payroll app -->
Payslips --> To Pay`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

![View all payslips that need to be paid on the Payslips To Pay page.](payslips/all-pay-slips.png)

Each payslip lists the `Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
number for the individual payslip, the `Employee`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} name, the `Batch Name`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, the `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the
`Basic
Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Gross Wage`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Net Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of the payslip.

Click on an individual payslip entry to view the details for that
individual payslip.

Process the payslips
`in the same way a regular payslip is processed <payroll/process>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, or in a batch.




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/salaries.md ---

# Salaries

In Odoo, salaries are calculated and determined by five factors: salary
`structure types
<payroll/structure-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, salary
`structures <payroll/structures>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, `rules
<payroll/rules>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"},
`rule parameters <payroll/rule-parameters>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, and `other input types
<payroll/other-input>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}. Together, these
determine how each employee\'s pay is calculated.

Each *structure type* contains one or more *structures* within it. Each
*structure* contains a set of *rules*, and every *rule* uses
*parameters* to define how specific amounts are calculated. Additional
inputs, (such as bonuses or deductions) can also be included to adjust
the final salary.

When payslips are calculated, Odoo calculates the employee\'s worked
time from their `work
entries <work_entries>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, then applies the
relevant structure, rules, and parameters from the employee\'s assigned
structure type to determine their total pay.

## Structure types {#payroll/structure-types}

In Odoo, a *structure type* groups related salary structures. When a
contract specifies a structure type, **only** the structures within that
type are used to calculate the employee\'s pay. Each structure type
houses individual structures within them, each containing a set of rules
for processing a timesheet entry.

Structure types define key aspects of payroll configuration, including
how often employees are paid, their working hours, the default salary
structure, and whether wages are fixed (salary-based) or variable
(hourly-based).

::: example
A structure type called [Employee]{.title-ref} contains two different
structures within it: a [Regular Pay]{.title-ref} structure which
includes all the separate rules for processing regular pay, and an [End
of Year Bonus]{.title-ref} structure, which includes the rules **only**
for the end of year bonus. Both belong to the same
[Employee]{.title-ref} structure type.
:::

View existing *structure types* by navigating to
`Payroll app --> Configuration -->
Structure Types`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Two default structure types are preconfigured in Odoo:
`Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Worker`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Typically, `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is used for
salaried employees, which is why the `Default
Wage Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is a
`Fixed Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Worker`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is typically used for
employees paid by the hour, so the wage type is
`Hourly Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If using a country-specific
`payroll localizations <payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, it is recommended to use the structure in the corresponding
country localization document.
::::

![List of all currently configured structure types available to use.](salaries/structure-type.png)

### New structure type {#payroll/new-structure-type}

If the default structure types do not meet the company\'s needs, go to
`Payroll app
--> Configuration --> Structure Types`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
to create a custom structure type.

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

When creating a new salary structure type, ensure all local and national
laws are accounted for. Confirm with the accounting department when
configuring payroll structures, to ensure all requirements are met.
::::

Proceed to enter the following information in the fields:

- `Structure Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the name
  for the new structure type, such as [Employee]{.title-ref} or
  [Worker]{.title-ref}.
- `Country`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the country that
  the new structure type applies to from the drop-down menu.
- `Wage Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the wage type
  for the structure:
  - `Fixed Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: For salaried
    employees who receive the same wage every pay period.
  - `Hourly Wage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: For employees paid
    based on hours worked during a pay period.
- `Default Scheduled Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the
  typical pay schedule for the new structure type from the drop-down
  menu. This indicates how often this specific type of structure is paid
  out.
- `Default Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the
  default working hours for the new structure type from the drop-down
  menu. All available working hours for the currently selected company
  appear in the drop-down menu. The default working hours are the
  `Standard 40 hours/week`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option. If
  the needed working hours do not appear in the list, a
  `new set of default working hours
  can be created <payroll/new-default-working-hours>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}.
- `Regular Pay Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Type in
  the name for the regular pay structure. It is used as the default
  option when generating payslips.
- `Default Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select
  the default work entry type which is used to create all work entries
  for the employee.

![New structure type form to fill out when creating a new structure type.](salaries/new-structure.png)

### New default working hours {#payroll/new-default-working-hours}

To make new default working hours, type the name for the new working
hours in the `Default
Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field on the new
structure type form. Click `Create and edit`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. A default working hours form pops up. The default
working hours form has two sections: a general information section, and
a tab listing all the individual working hours by day and time. When the
form is completed, click `Save & Close`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

- `Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Type in the name for the
  new default working hours. This should be descriptive and clear to
  understand, such as [Standard 20 Hours/Week]{.title-ref}.

- `Flexible Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Check the
  checkbox to let employees adjust their start and end times while
  maintaining the same total daily hours.

- `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
  number of hours per week an employee needs to work to be considered a
  full-time employee. Typically, this is approximately 40 hours, and
  this number affects what types of benefits an employee can receive,
  based on their employment status (full-time vs part-time).

- `Average Hour Per Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  Auto-populated based on the working hours in the
  `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab. This entry
  affects resource planning by determining how many resources can be
  used per workday.

- `Work Time Rate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This percentage
  is auto-generated based on the entry for the
  `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the working
  hours configured in the `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} tab. This number should be between
  [0.00%]{.title-ref} and [100%]{.title-ref}, so if the percentage is
  above [100%]{.title-ref}, it is an indication that the working times
  and/or `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} hours
  need adjustment.

- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the company that
  can use these new default working hours from the drop-down menu. Leave
  this field blank if the hours are available for all companies.

- `Timezone`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the time zone to
  be used for the new default working hours from the drop-down menu.

- `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} Tab: This tab is
  where each day\'s specific working hours are listed. When a new
  default working hour form is created, the
  `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab is
  pre-populated with a default 40-hour week, with each day divided into
  three timed sections.

  Each day includes morning (8:00--12:00), lunch (12:00--13:00), and
  afternoon (13:00--17:00) periods, configured using the 24-hour time
  format.

  To adjust any of these hours, click the field and modify the time
  using the drop-down menus, or type the desired time directly.

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  Working hours are company-specific, and cannot be shared between
  companies.
  ::::

  :::: tip
  ::: title
  Tip
  :::

  If the working hours are not consistent each week, and the hours are
  on a bi-weekly schedule instead, click the
  `Switch to 2 week calendar`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button
  at the top of the new default working hours form. This changes the
  `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab to display two
  weeks of working times that can be adjusted.
  ::::

## Structures {#payroll/structures}

*Salary structures* are the different situations in which an employee
could be paid within a specific *structure*, and are specifically
defined by various rules.

The number of structures a company needs for each structure type depends
on how many different ways employees are paid, and how their pay is
calculated. A common example of an additional structure is a
[Bonus]{.title-ref}.

To view all the various structures for each structure type, go to
`Payroll app -->
Configuration --> Structures`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Each `structure type <payroll/structure-types>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} lists the various structures associated with it. Each
structure contains a set of rules that define it.

![All available salary structures.](salaries/salary-structure.png)

Click on a structure to view its `Salary Rules`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. These rules define how the payslip will be computed
for the employee.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

After installing a
`payroll localization <payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, relevant structures are installed and appear in this list.
::::

![Salary structure details for Regular Pay, listing all the specific Salary Rules.](salaries/structure-regular-pay-rules.png)

## Salary rules {#payroll/rules}

Each *structure* has a set of salary *rules* used to compute the various
amounts considered in the pay. These rules are configured by the
localization and affect the computation of the salaries.

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

Modification or creation of rules should **only** be done when
necessary.
::::

To view all the rules, go to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Rules`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Click on a structure (such as
`Regular Pay`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}) to view all the rules.

### Add a new rule

To make a new rule, click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and a
blank `Salary Rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form loads.
Enter the following information in the top half of the form:

- `Rule Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a name for the
  rule. This is the name displayed in the payslip.
- `Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a code to be used for
  the new rule. This is case sensitive and is used as the *rule ID*.
  This field is **required**.
- `Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the category the rule applies to, or enter a new
  category. The category is used to group rules and access their total
  sum.
- `Salary Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select the salary structure the rule applies to, or
  enter a new one. This field is **required**.
- `Sequence`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a number
  indicating *when* the rule is calculated, in the sequence of all other
  rules. Rules are processed one after another based on their sequence
  number. Rules with a lower sequence number are calculated first, and
  their results can be used by rules with a higher sequence number. This
  field is **required**.
- `Appears on Payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Check the
  checkbox to have the rule visible on the employee payslip PDF.
- `Contributes to Employer Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  Check the checkbox to include the rule when computing the *employer
  cost* of a payslip.

#### General tab

Fill out the following sections of the `General`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab. These configurations determine *when* and *how*
the rule is calculated.

##### Conditions

- `Condition Based on`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select if the rule is calculated and displayed as a
  line in the payslip form view. Choose from one of the following
  options:
  - `Always True`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The rule is always
    calculated. No other configurations are needed for this section.

  - `Salary Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This introduces a
    dynamic benefit to the structure. This appears as a field in the
    *Payroll* tab of the *Employee* form, the *Inputs* tab of the
    payslip, or both. The value of this field is added to the amount of
    the rule. If selected, the following additional fields appear and
    must be configured:

    - `Input on`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Specify where this
      field should appear and which object it should belong to, the
      `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the
      `Payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or both. If both are
      selected, the value on the payslip automatically defaults to the
      value from the employee record, but it can be overwritten directly
      on the payslip for a specific payroll run.

    - `Section`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This groups several
      inputs into one expandable section on the form view. Only one
      option is available by default, `Inputs`{.interpreted-text
      role="guilabel"}.

    - `Unit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Click the corresponding
      radio button to determine how the benefit is displayed. The
      available options are:

      - `Monetary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A number with
        currency.
      - `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A number.
      - `Percentage`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A number with a
        % sign.
      - `Checkbox`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Indicates boolean
        values.

    - `Input Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a
      short explanation of when the input is applicable.

    - `Default Value`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
      default value, either a monetary amount, quantity, or percentage.
      This is determined by what is selected for the
      `Unit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. If necessary, add a
      `Suffix`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the field to the
      right of this value, such as [per km]{.title-ref}.

      :::: note
      ::: title
      Note
      :::

      If `Checkbox`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is selected for
      the `Unit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, this field changes
      to `Selected by Default`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Click
      the checkbox to have the rule active by default.
      ::::

    > - `Depends On`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select another
    >   rule that has a salary input, and use its value to determine
    >   whether this rule should be hidden.

  - `Other Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this to
    check if a payslip line exists with the same *type*. When selected,
    a `Condition Other Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field
    appears. Using the drop-down menu, select the type of input the rule
    is based on, such as `Deduction`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
    `Reimbursement`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, etc.

  - `Python Expression`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this
    to have the rule calculated using a Python script. The script is
    evaluated using the local dictionary. The right side lists the
    `Available variables`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the
    `Output`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:

    - `Available variables`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
      - `payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
        [hr.payslip]{.title-ref} object.
      - `employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
        [hr.employee]{.title-ref} object.
      - `version`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
        [hr.version]{.title-ref} object.
      - `result_rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dictionary
        containing the rules amounts, quantities, rates and totals
        (previously computed).
      - `categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dictionary
        containing the computed salary rule categories (the sum of the
        amount of all the rules belonging to that category):
        - `total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule total
        - `amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule amount
        - `quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule quantity
        - `rate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule rate
        - `ytd`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule year to date
          value
      - `worked_days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dictionary
        containing the computed worked days, where each key is a work
        entry type code, and each value is a [worked_days]{.title-ref}
        object. This object contains many variables, with the most
        important ones being:
        - `number_of_days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
          number of days registered in the payslip duration with this
          work entry type.
        - `number_of_hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The
          number of hours registered in the payslip duration with this
          work entry type.
        - `is_paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Whether or not
          this work entry type is added as an unpaid work entry on this
          payslip structure.
      - `inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dictionary
        containing the computed inputs where *key* is the other input
        type code and *value* is the sum of the payslip input lines with
        the same code.
    - `Output`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
      - `result`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The boolean is
        *True* if the rule should be calculated, or *False* if
        otherwise.
- `Domain`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this option to
  apply the rule *only* if it matches the configured
  `Applicability Domain`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Configure
  the `Applicability Domain`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} that
  appears beneath this option when selected.

##### Computation

This section determines the final value of the rule, which consists of
the base amount, the quantity, and the rate. The total of the rule is
[total = amount \* quantity \* (rate/100)]{.title-ref}.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

This field does **not** appear if the
`Condition Based on`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is set to
`Salary Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
::::

Using the drop-down menu, select one of the following options for the
`Amount Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field:

- `Percentage (%)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Defines the
  values for the total calculation. When selected, configure the
  following fields:
  - `Percentage based on`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A Python
    expression is evaluated using the [localdict]{.title-ref}, and its
    value is assigned to the rule amount.
  - `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A Python expression
    is evaluated using the [localdict]{.title-ref}, and its value is
    assigned to the rule quantity.
  - `Percentage (%)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A decimal
    number assigned to the rule rate.
- `Fixed Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The amount and
  quantity is defined, with a rate of 100%.
  - `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A Python expression
    is evaluated using the [localdict]{.title-ref}, and its value is
    assigned to the rule quantity.
  - `Fixed Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a decimal
    number which is assigned to the rule amount.
- `Other Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select this to fetch
  the rule amount from the payslip input lines that have the same *other
  input type* with rate of [100%]{.title-ref} and quantity of
  [1.0]{.title-ref}. When selected, an
  `Amount Other Input`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field appears
  beneath it. Using the drop-down menu, select the *type* of input it
  is, such as `Deduction`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
  `Tips`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
  `Expenses`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
- `Python Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This is the more
  complex version of the `Percentage (%)`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} option, where a whole Python script is written then
  evaluated using the [localdict]{.title-ref}. This includes a list of
  `Available variables`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and an
  `Output`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} list.
  - `Available variables`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
    - `payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: hr.payslip object
    - `employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: hr.employee object
    - `version`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: hr.version object
    - `result_rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dict
      containing the rules amounts, quantities, rates and totals
      (previously computed), where the key is the rule code, and the
      value is dict with the following keys:
      - `total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule total
      - `amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule amount
      - `quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule quantity
      - `rate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule rate
      - `ytd`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: rule year to date
        value
    - `categories`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dict containing
      the computed salary rule categories (sum of amount of all rules
      belonging to that category) where key is the category code and
      value is the sum of the rules total values.
    - `worked_days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dict
      containing the computed worked days where *key* is the work entry
      type code and *value* is the [worked_days]{.title-ref} object
      contain many variables, but most important ones are:
      - `number_of_days`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The number
        of days registered in the payslip duration with this work entry
        type.
      - `number_of_hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The number
        of hours registered in the payslip duration with this work entry
        type.
      - `is_paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Dictates whether
        or not this work entry type is added as unpaid work entry on
        this payslip structure.
    - `inputs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: A dict containing the
      computed inputs Where *key*\* is the other input type code and
      *value* is the sum of the payslip input lines with the same code.
  - `Output`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
    - `result`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: float, base amount of
      the rule
    - `result_rate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: float, which
      defaults to 100.0 (%)
    - `result_qty`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: float, quantity,
      which defaults to 1
    - `result_name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: string, name of
      the line. This defaults to the name field of the salary rule
      (useful if the name depends or should depend on something computed
      in the rule).

##### Company contribution

Using the drop-down menu, select the eventual third party involved in
the salary payment to the employees.

#### Display tab

This section determines the appearance of the rule on the payslip PDF
available to the employee, and defines the rule aesthetics.

First, select a `Color`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for the rule
using the color picker. Next, check the `Title`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} checkbox to **only** display the salary rule\'s *title*
and *description*, and hide any numerical values.

Check the `Indented`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Space Above`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Bold`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Underline`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, and `Italic`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
checkboxes to activate the options.

Finally, enter a `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for
the rule, which is displayed below the rule name.

#### Accounting tab

This section determines how the rule affects the various accounting
journals and how the Net salary is calculated for employees. Configure
the following fields in this section:

- `Debit Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select the debit account for the rule.
- `Credit Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the
  drop-down menu, select the credit account for the rule.
- `Split on names`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enable this
  option to split the accounting entries for this rule according to the
  payslip line name. Splitting the entries provides more visibility for
  deductions and reimbursements, or for salary adjustments.
- `Excluded from Net`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Check this
  checkbox to exclude the rule\'s calculations from the net salary rule
  in journal entries. A specific debit and credit account should be set
  to independently classify it.
- `Set employee on account line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  Check this checkbox to have the employee\'s name visible on the
  journal items.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

This tab is **only** available if the **Accounting** app is installed.
::::

## Rule parameters {#payroll/rule-parameters}

Rule parameters inform Odoo how to calculate each line of a payslip. To
view the configured rule parameters, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Rule Parameters`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

All rule parameters are displayed. Click on an individual rule parameter
to view the details.

Each rule parameter displays the name of the rule, the code, when the
rule is active, and the parameter value.

::: example
The rule parameters for overtime pay inform Odoo that employees receive
time and a half when working over 40 hours.
:::

## Other input types {#payroll/other-input}

When creating payslips, it is sometimes necessary to add other entries
for specific circumstances, like tips, commissions, expenses, or
deductions. These other inputs can be found by navigating to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Other Input Types`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

![A list of other input types for payroll that can be selected when creating a new entry for
a payslip.](salaries/other-input.png)

If a new input type is needed that does not appear on the list, click
the `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to create a new
input type. Enter the `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
the `Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and select which
structure it applies to in the
`Availability in Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.

Check the `Available in attachments`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
checkbox if the input should be a salary attachment.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

The `Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is used in the salary
rules to compute payslips. If the
`Availability in Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is
left blank, it indicates that the new input type is available for all
payslips and is not exclusive to a specific structure.
::::

![A new Input Type form filled in.](salaries/input-type-new.png)




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/salary_attachments.md ---

# Salary adjustments

Salary adjustments are portions of earnings taken directly out of a
payslip for a specific purpose, whether voluntary or required.

When the deduction is voluntary, they are typically considered
*deductions*. When the deduction is court-ordered, or involuntary, it is
sometimes referred to as a *wage garnishment*. In Odoo, these are all
universally called *salary adjustments*.

Note that salary adjustments can also be used to give recurring amounts
of money to employees, like a bonus divided into multiple payments.

## Salary adjustment types {#payroll/salary-adjustment/types}

To view the currently configured salary adjustment types, navigate to
`Payroll app
--> Configuration --> Other Input Types`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. This displays *all* other salary inputs, not only
the various salary adjustments.

The three default salary adjustment types that appear in this list are:
`Attachment of
Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Assignment of Salary`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Child Support`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Each salary adjustment type displays the `Name`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} of the adjustment type, and the
`Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} used when calculating
payslips.

![The default salary adjustment types.](salary_attachments/adjustment-types.png)

### Create new salary adjustment types

:::: danger
::: title
Danger
:::

Upon installation of the **Payroll** application, the preconfigured
default salary adjustment types are linked to a variety of rules that
are linked to various salary structures, as well as the installed
`localization package <fiscal_localizations/packages>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

It is **not** recommended to alter or modify **any** of the
preconfigured salary adjustment types, especially if they have been
previously used on payslips in the database. Doing so may affect various
salary rules, and can prevent the creation of payslips.

A new salary adjustment type *can* be created, but this should only be
done when absolutely necessary. A salary adjustment type **must** be
linked to a salary rule to be considered in the salary computation.
::::

To make a new type of salary adjustment, click the
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and a blank
`Payslip Other Input Types`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form
loads. Enter the `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for
the new salary adjustment type in the corresponding field. Next, tick
the `Available in
adjustments`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} checkbox, indicating it
is available to use as a salary adjustment. Enter the
`Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} used in the salary rules to
compute payslips. Lastly, if the salary adjustment type should **only**
be used in a specific payroll structure, use the drop-down menu in the
`Available in Structure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and
select the specific structure.

## Create a salary adjustment {#payroll/salary-adjustment/create}

All salary adjustments must be configured separately for each employee,
for each type of salary adjustment. To view the currently configured
salary adjustments, navigate to `Payroll
app --> Employees --> Salary Adjustments`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

All salary adjustments appear in a default list view, and displays the
name of the `Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the
`Start Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, a descriptive
`Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the salary adjustment
`Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. An
`Until`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column appears as well, which
details when the salary adjustment ends, either a monetary amount to be
reached, or `Indefinite`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} if the
adjustment has no end.

At the end of each line is a status tag, with a green
`Running`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tag for active adjustments,
or `Closed`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for adjustments that have
ended.

To create a new salary adjustment, click the `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button in the top-left corner, and a blank
`Salary Adjustment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form loads. Enter
the following information on the form:

- `Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down
  menu, select the desired employees. Multiple employees can be listed
  in this field.

- `Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the drop-down menu,
  select the specific `salary adjustment type
  <payroll/salary-adjustment/types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

- `Payslip Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the amount
  taken out of each paycheck in this field.

- `Negative Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this
  checkbox if the salary adjustment is taken into account as a negative
  value.

- `Duration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the length of
  time for the salary adjustment. The options are:

  - `One Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Only one payment is
    taken from the employee\'s paycheck.
  - `Limited`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The employee is paying
    a specific monetary amount in total, divided up among multiple
    paychecks.
  - `Unlimited`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The employee is
    making recurring payments towards something with no end point, such
    as contributions to a retirement fund, or a donation to a charity.
  - `from`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Using the calendar
    selector, select the date the salary adjustment goes into effect.

  :::: note
  ::: title
  Note
  :::

  If the `Duration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field is set to
  `Limited`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, an `until (amount)
  paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field appears. Enter the
  monetary amount that must be reached, before the salary adjustment
  ends.
  ::::

- `Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a short description
  of the salary adjustment.

![The salary adjustment form with all fields filled out.](salary_attachments/salary-adjustment-form.png)

Since the salary adjustment form auto-saves as the fields are populated,
after making a salary adjustment for an individual employee, there is no
further action required.

If creating salary adjustments for multiple employees on a single salary
adjustment form, after the form is filled out, click the
`Create Individual Attachments`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button. This creates separate salary adjustments for each of the
employees listed in the `Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field.

After the separate salary adjustments have been created, the screen
returns to the `Salary
Adjustment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard, but with a
`Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} filter, populated with the
information filled in the `Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field on the salary adjustment form. All the salary adjustments have a
status of `Running`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, since they are
currently active. Clear the filter in the search box to view the default
`Salary Adjustment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard in its
entirety.

## Manage salary adjustments

Salary adjustments can have one of two statuses, *Running* or *Closed*.
To view the current status of all salary adjustments, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Employees --> Salary
Adjustments`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

All salary adjustments appear in chronological order, by
`Start Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, with the most recent
appearing at the top. To view the salary adjustments by a particular
metric, such as the `Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, or
`Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, click on the column title to
sort by that specific column.

![All salary adjustments, organized by start date.](salary_attachments/adjustments-list.png)

### Closed salary adjustments

When a salary adjustment is created, it has a status of
`Running`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Once the salary adjustment
is finished (the *Until* amount entered on the `salary adjustment form
<payroll/salary-adjustment/create>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} has
been paid in full), the status automatically changes to *Closed*, and
the employee no longer has money taken out of future paychecks.

If a salary adjustment has been fulfilled, but has not automatically
changed to *Closed*, the record can be manually updated. To change the
status, open the *Salary Adjustment* dashboard by navigating to
`Payroll app --> Employees --> Salary Adjustments`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

Click on the record to update, and the detailed
`Salary Adjustment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form loads. On
the individual `Salary Adjustment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
record, click the `Mark as Completed`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button in the upper-left corner, and the status changes to
`Closed`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

::: example
The following is an example of when a payroll manager may need to
manually change a salary adjustment from `Running`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to `Closed`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Rose Smith has a salary adjustment for a lawsuit settlement, where she
is required to pay \$3,000.00. A salary adjustment is created that takes
\$250.00 a month out of Rose\'s paycheck, to go towards this settlement
payment.

After six months, Rose has paid \$1,500.00 from her salary. She receives
a tax refund, and uses the money to pay off the remainder of the lawsuit
settlement. After sending the relevant documentation to the payroll
manager, showing the settlement has been paid in full, the payroll
manager manually changes the status of her salary adjustment to
`Closed`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
:::




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/time_off_to_report.md ---

# Time off to report

Payroll is often processed a few days before the end of a pay period, so
that employees can be paid in a timely manner. When work schedules are
predictable, this method often works. However, sometimes employees take
time off unexpectedly, especially sick time. When this occurs, there can
be discrepancies in payroll that must be addressed.

::: example
The payroll department for a medium-sized company processes paychecks
every two weeks, on Wednesdays. Each employee is paid on the Friday
after.

One employee is sick on the last Thursday and Friday of the two-week pay
period. Since they have automatically generated work entries based on
their working schedule, and payroll is processed on Wednesdays, the
paycheck they receive incorrectly states that they were paid for a
regular work day for all ten days of the two-week pay period.

Instead of cancelling the paycheck and reissuing it, causing delays for
the employee and more work for the payroll department, Odoo allows for
the deferral of the time off taken, to the following pay period.

This ensures all time off balances are correct, and the employee is
properly compensated for their time.
:::

## Time off dashboard {#payroll/time-off-dashboard}

When time off requests are submitted for a time period that was already
processed on a payslip, the time off requests appear in the *Time Off*
page of the **Payroll** app. To access this, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Work Entries --> Time Off to Report`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

The `Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page default filter is
`To Defer`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and displays all requests
with a `Payslip State`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of
`To defer to next payslip`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This is
because the employee was *already paid* for that time as worked time,
and it was logged as regular time spent at work.

![A list of all time off requests that were not approved before payslips were generated.](time_off_to_report/time-off-to-report.png)

## Defer multiple time off entries

In order to keep the employee\'s time off balances correct, the time off
request **must** be applied to the following pay period. This not only
ensures time off request balances are current, it also eliminates the
need to redo work entries, cancel paychecks, and reissue paychecks.

To select the work entries to defer, tick the box to the left of the
work entry line on the
`Time Off page <payroll/time-off-dashboard>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}. To select all work entries in the list, tick the box to the
left of the `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column title,
at the top of the list.

Once any work entry is selected, two buttons appear at the top of the
report: a `(#)
selected`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button, and an
`fa-gear`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} `Actions`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button. The `(#) selected`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button indicates how many entries are currently
selected.

When all the desired work entries are selected, click the
`fa-gear`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} `Actions`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button, and a menu appears with several choices. Click
`Defer to Next Month`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the list,
and all selected entries are deferred to the following month.

## Defer individual time off entries

Time off requests appearing on the
`Time Off page <payroll/time-off-dashboard>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} can be deferred individually. Click on an individual time
off request, and the details for that request load.

The specific details for the time off request appear on the left-hand
side, and all of the employee\'s submitted time off requests appear on
the right-hand side (including the request in the details on the
left-hand side).

To defer the time off request to the next payslip, click the
`Report to Next Month`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the
upper-left corner. Once processed, the
`Report to Next Month`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button
disappears, and the `Payslip State`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
changes from `To defer to next payslip`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to `Computed in Current Payslip`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

![The time off details for an individual request that needs to be deferred.](time_off_to_report/single-defer.png)




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/work_entries.md ---

# Work entries

A *work entry* is an individual record on an employee\'s timesheet. Work
entries can be configured to account for all types of work and time off,
such as `Attendance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Sick Time
Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, `Training`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, or `Public Holiday`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

The **Payroll** app automatically creates work entries based on the
employee\'s `salary
structure type <payroll/structure-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"},
and from the **Planning**, **Attendances**, and **Time Off**
applications. When needed, work entries can also be `created manually
<payroll/new-work-entry>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

Work entries provide the **Payroll** app with the worked hours used to
compute employee paychecks, if the employee\'s salary is based on work
entries, as opposed to a salaried position.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Odoo configures several work entry types by default, but
`additional work entry types can be
created <payroll/work-entry-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, when
necessary.
::::

## Work entry dashboard {#payroll/work-entry-dashboard}

The *Work Entries* dashboard of the **Payroll** app provides a visual
overview of the individual work entries for every employee.

To open the dashboard, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Work Entries --> Work Entries`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

On the `Work Entry`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard, work
entries appear in alphabetical order, based on the first name of the
employees. The entire month is displayed, with the current day
highlighted in pale yellow.

The `Work Entry`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard has a
default `Conflicting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} filter, which
displays only work entries with
`conflicts <payroll/conflicts>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} to be
resolved.

![Conflicts dashboard view showing all employee\'s conflicts in work entries.](work_entries/work-entries-overview.png)

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Remove the default `Conflicting`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
filter from the search bar to view *all* work entries.
::::

## Add a new work entry {#payroll/new-work-entry}

If a work entry is missing, such as sick time, or if an employee forgot
to clock in and out for a shift, a new work entry must be created for
the missing shift.

Click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} on the
`work entry dashboard <payroll/work-entry-dashboard>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, and a blank `Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
work entry pop-up form appears. Enter the following information on the
form:

- `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a short
  description for the work entry, such as [Sick Time]{.title-ref}. The
  default entry is [Attendance: (Employee)]{.title-ref}.

- `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the employee the
  work entry is for, using the drop-down menu.

- `Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the
  `Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} using the
  drop-down menu.

- `From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and `To`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}: Enter the start (`From`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}) and end (`To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"})
  dates and times for the work entry.

  First, click on either the `From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
  or `To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} line to reveal a calendar
  pop-up window. Select the date by navigating to the correct month,
  then click on the specific day to select it.

  Next, select the time, by clicking on either the hour or minute fields
  at the bottom of the calendar, and set the desired time.

  When the date and time for the entry are correct, click the
  `Apply`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button.

- `Duration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This field displays the
  hours based on the `To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
  `From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} entries. Modifying this
  field modifies the `To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field (the
  `From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field does not change).

Once the desired information is entered, click
`Save & Close`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to save the entry, and
close the pop-up form.

![Filling in the work entry Create form in Odoo.](work_entries/create.png)

## Conflicts {#payroll/conflicts}

A conflict occurs when a request has not been approved, such as sick
time or vacation, or if there are any errors on the work entry.
Conflicts that span the current pay period being processed **must** be
resolved before payslips can be generated.

Any work entry that has a conflict to be resolved is indicated on the
main `Work Entry`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard, which
can be accessed by navigating to `Payroll app --> Work Entries -->
Work Entries`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. Only conflicts
needing resolution are shown by default.

Conflicts are indicated with an orange triangle in the top-left corner
of each individual work entry. Click on an individual work entry to see
the date and time for the specific work entry, then click
`Edit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to view the conflict details
in a pop-up window.

![A row of conflicts, with one entry showing details for the conflict.](work_entries/conflict-pop-up.png)

The conflict is briefly explained in an orange text box in the
`Open`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window that appears.

The `Description`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} are listed on the
left side of the pop-up window. The `From`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} and `To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} date and
time range, as well as the total time (in hours) in the
`Duration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, appears on the
right side.

### Time off conflicts

The most common work entry conflicts are for time off requests. Odoo
automatically generates work entries for specific time periods. When
time off is requested after these work entries are generated, it results
in duplicate work entries for that employee (one for time off and
another for regular work).

If there is a conflict because a time off request is in the system for
the same time that a regular work entry already exists, the time off
request is entered in a `Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field.

Conflicts can be resolved either directly on the work entry or in the
detailed time off request form.

#### Resolve on work entry {#payroll/time-off-work-entry}

If no additional details are needed to determine if a time off request
should be approved or refused, the time off conflict can be resolved
directly from the work entry pop-up window.

Click either the `Refuse Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Approve Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} buttons to refuse
or approve the time off request, then the two buttons disappear. Click
the `Save & Close`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to close
the pop-up window.

The conflict disappears from the `Work Entry`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard, since the conflict is now resolved.

![The detailed conflict pop-up window that appears when the Edit button is clicked.](work_entries/conflict-details.png)

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If the time off is approved, the status of the work entry conflict
changes to `Cancelled`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. If the time
off is refused, the status changes to `Draft`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.
::::

#### Resolve on time off request {#payroll/time-off-request-form}

If more details are needed to make a decision about the time off
request, hover over the entry in the `Time Off`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, and click the
`fa-external-link`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(Internal Link)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon that appears
at the end of the line. This causes an
`Open: Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window to
load, with all the time off request details. Click either the
`Approve`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Refuse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} buttons to approve or refuse
the request.

To resolve the time off conflict on the detailed time off request pop-up
window, click the `Internal Link`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button at the end of the `Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
entry line, and the time off request details appear in a new pop-up
window. The request can be modified, if needed.

Click the `Approve`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to approve
the request, then click the `Save & Close`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button to save the changes, and go back to the work
entry conflict pop-up window.

![The detailed time off request information.](work_entries/entry-details.png)

Now, the `Approve Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button is
hidden, only the `Refuse Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button is visible.

If the approval was a mistake, the request can be refused here, by
clicking the `Refuse
Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button.

Since the time off was approved in the time off window, click the
`X`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the top-right corner to close
the window. The conflict disappears from the
`Work Entry`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard, since it has
been resolved.

## Regenerate work entries {#payroll/regenerate-work-entries}

After conflicts are resolved, the affected work entries must be
regenerated. This recreates the specified work entries, and overwrites
the previously conflicting work entries.

While `conflicts <payroll/conflicts>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
*can* be resolved individually, if the conflicts are caused by another
application, such as **Planning** or **Attendances**, it is best
practice to correct the record in the application causing the conflict.
The reason this method is recommended is because, if the issue in the
related application is **not** resolved, when work entries are
regenerated, the conflicts reappear.

First, ensure the issues are resolved in the specific applications that
caused the work entry conflicts. Once the conflicts have been resolved
in the corresponding apps, open the work entry dashboard by navigating
to `Payroll app --> Work Entries --> Work Entries`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

Click the `Regenerate Work Entries`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button at the top of the `Work Entries`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard, and a
`Work Entry Regeneration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window appears.

Select the `Employees`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to regenerate
work entries for, using the drop-down menu. Adjust the
`From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and `To`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} fields, so the correct date range is displayed.

Click the `Regenerate Work Entries`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button, and the work entries are recreated. Once finished, the pop-up
window closes.

![Regenerate a work entry for a particular employee.](work_entries/regenerate-details.png)

::: example
An employee has incorrect work entries generated from the **Planning**
app because they were incorrectly assigned to two work stations
simultaneously. This should be fixed in the **Planning** app, instead of
the **Payroll** app.

To correct this issue, modify the employee\'s schedule in the
**Planning** app, so they are correctly assigned to only one work
station. Then, in the **Payroll** app, regenerate work entries for that
employee, for that specific time period.

The **Payroll** app then pulls the new, corrected data form the
**Planning** app, and recreates the correct work entries for that
employee. All conflicts for that employee are now resolved.
:::

## Work entry types {#payroll/work-entry-types}

When `creating a work entry <payroll/new-work-entry>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} in the **Payroll** application, or when a new time off type
is created in the **Time Off** application, a work entry *type* needs to
be selected.

The **Payroll** app comes with nine preconfigured work entry types, and
depending on the installed
`payroll localization <payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, additional country-specific work entries may be configured.
If there is a need for additional work entry types, they can be `created
<payroll/new-work-entry-type>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

To view the current work entry types available, navigate to
`Payroll app -->
Configuration --> Work Entries --> Work Entry Types`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}.

Each work entry type has a code to aid in the creation of payslips, and
to ensure all taxes and fees are correctly entered.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Depending on the installed localization, other sections and fields may
appear on the form.
::::

![List of all work entry types currently available for use, with the payroll code and color.](work_entries/work-entry-types.png)

### New work entry type {#payroll/new-work-entry-type}

To create a new work entry type, go to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Work
Entries --> Work Entry Types`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}
and click `New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, enter the
information for the following sections on the form.

#### General information section

- `Work Entry Type Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a
  name for the work entry type. It should be short and descriptive, such
  as [Sick Time]{.title-ref} or [Training]{.title-ref}.
- `Payroll Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a code for
  the work entry type. This code appears with the work entry type on
  timesheets and payslips. Since the code is used in conjunction with
  the **Accounting** application, it is advised to check with the
  accounting department for a code to use.
- `External Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter a code to
  use for exporting data to a third-party payroll service. Check with
  the third-party being used to determine the
  `External Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to enter for the
  new work entry type.
- `Color`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select a color for the
  particular work entry type. This color appears on the work entry
  dashboard to aid in identifying work entry types.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The **only** required fields for a work entry type is the
`Work Entry Type Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the
`Payroll Code`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
::::

#### Display in payslip section

- `Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select how the time
  entered for the work entry should be rounded. The rounding method
  selected determines how the worked time on timesheet entries are
  calculated. The options are:
  - `No Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Work entries are
    not modified.
  - `Half Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Work entries are
    rounded to the closest half day amount.
  - `Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Work entries are rounded
    to the closest full day amount.
- `Rounding Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If either
  `Half Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
  `Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is selected in the
  `Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, this field
  appears. Select either `Up`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
  `Down`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to determine how the
  rounding is handled.

::: example
The working time is set to an 8-hour work day (a 40-hour work week). An
employee enters a time of 5.5 hours on a work entry.

If the `Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`No Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the work entry remains
at 5.5 hours.

If the `Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`Half Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Rounding Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`Down`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the work entry is changed to
4 hours. If the `Rounding Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is
set to `Up`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the work entry is
changed to 8 hours.

If the `Rounding`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Rounding Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`Down`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the work entry is changed to
zero hours. If the `Rounding Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is
set to `Up`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, the work entry is
changed to 8 hours.
:::

#### Unpaid section

- `Unpaid in Structures Types`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: If
  the work entry type is for work that is *not paid*, specify which pay
  structure the unpaid work entry type applies to, using the drop-down
  menu. Some situations where work is logged on a payslip, but no
  compensation is given, such as unpaid internships, unpaid training, or
  volunteer work.

#### Time off options section

- `Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this box if the
  work entry type can be selected for a time off request or time off
  entry, in the **Time Off** application.

  If `Time Off`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is active, a
  `Time Off Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field appears. This
  field has a drop-down menu to select the specific types of time off,
  such as [Paid Time Off]{.title-ref}, [Sick Time Off]{.title-ref}, or
  [Extra Hours]{.title-ref}. Select the
  `Time Off Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} associated with the
  work entry type.

- `Keep Time Off Right`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this
  checkbox if the work entry type associated with the selected time off
  type allows for rolling over unused time off to the following year.

#### Reporting section

- `Unforeseen Absence`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this box
  if the work entry type should be visible on the unforeseen absences
  report.

![New work entry type form with all fields to be filled in.](work_entries/new-work-entry-type.png)

::: seealso
`payslips`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}

`pay_runs`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/work_entry_analysis.md ---

# Work entry analysis

The default *Work Entries Analysis* report provides an overview of the
validated work entries for the current month. To view this report,
navigate to `Payroll app --> Reporting -->
Work Entry Analysis`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

The work entries appear in a pivot table, with the default filters of
`Current month:
(Month)(Year)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Validated`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. The various types of
`work_entries`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} populate the rows, while
the `Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} values populate the only
visible column.

To change the displayed information, click
`fa-plus-square`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} above the main column,
revealing a drop-down menu of available metrics. Click on one of the
available groupings, and the data is further organized by that selected
metric. The default options are `Work
Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Department`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. If in a multi-company
database, a `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option also
appears.

## Work entry analysis comparison

It is possible to compare the work entries from one time period to a
previous time period. To view this comparison, first navigate to
`Payroll app --> Reporting --> Work Entry
Analysis`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Next, click the `fa-caret-down`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(down arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon in the search
bar, revealing a drop-down menu. Under the `fa-adjust`{.interpreted-text
role="icon"} `Comparison`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section,
click on either `Current Month: Previous Period`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} or `Current Month: Previous Year`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

The report updates and displays the data for the current time period,
data for the selected previous time period, as well as the
`Variation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} between the two, in a
percentage.

![A pivot table comparing the work entries of the current month and the previous month.](work_entry_analysis/work-entry-comparison.png)

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If no work entries for a specific
`work entry type <payroll/work-entry-types>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} are logged for the time period, it does **not** appear on
the report. That does **not** mean the work entry type does not exist,
or is not configured.

Additionally, if the default
`Current month: (Month)(Year)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} filter
is removed from the search bar, the `Comparison`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column does **not** appear; there must be a time-frame
selected to view the `Comparison`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
column.
::::

## Use case: overtime report comparison

It is possible to alter the *Work Entries Analysis* report to show a
comparison of only overtime work entries, grouped by employee, for a
specific time period. To view this data, first navigate to the default
*Work entry analysis* report by going to `Payroll app --> Reporting -->
Work Entry Analysis`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Next, click the `fa-caret-down`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(down arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon in the search
bar, revealing a drop-down menu. Under the `fa-filter`{.interpreted-text
role="icon"} `Filters`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, click
`Add Custom
Filter`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and a
`Add Custom Filter`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window
appears.

Using the drop-down menu, select `Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} for the first field, leave the middle field as-is (with
`is in`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} populating the field), and
select `Overtime Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for the last
field. Click `Add`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and all other
work entry types disappear, and `Overtime Hours`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} appear in the sole row.

To compare overtime from the current month to the previous month, to see
which month had more overtime logged, click the
`fa-caret-down`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`(down arrow)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon again in the
search bar. Under the `fa-adjust`{.interpreted-text role="icon"}
`Comparison`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section, click
`Current Month:
Previous Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Click away from the
drop-down menu to close it.

Now, the report displays the `Overtime Hours`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} for the current month and the previous month, along
with the `Variation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, in a
percentage.

To view which employees received the most overtime, click
`fa-plus-square`{.interpreted-text role="icon"} `Overtime
Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, revealing a drop-down menu of
options. Click `Employee`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and all
employees with overtime work entries for either the current or previous
month appears.

In this example, it can be determined that `Marc Demo`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} worked the most overtime in
`August 2024`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, whereas
`Beth Evans`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} worked the most overtime
hours in `September 2024`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
Additionally, `Mitchell Admin`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} had
the largest variation change, with a `-100%`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} change from `August 2024`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to `September 2024`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![A pivot table comparing the overtime from September 2024 with August 2024.](work_entry_analysis/variation.png)




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll/working_schedules.md ---

# Working schedules

In Odoo, *working schedules* determine the hours employees are expected
to work, according to their `contract <contracts>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, and informs the **Payroll** app how to compute work
entries, ultimately affecting salaries and payslips. It is necessary to
ensure all working schedules for employees are configured in the
database.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

In Odoo\'s **Payroll** app, *working schedules* are referred to as
*working hours* in `salary
structures <payroll/structure-types>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
::::

To view the currently configured working schedules, navigate to
`Payroll app -->
Configuration --> Working Schedules`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and the `Working Schedules`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} dashboard loads.

Working schedules are company-specific. In a multi-company database,
each company **must** identify each type of working schedule they use.
If the database is created for only one company, the
`Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column is not available.

::: example
An Odoo database containing multiple companies that use a standard
40-hour work week needs to have a separate working schedule entry for
each company that uses the 40-hour standard work week.

A database with five companies that all use a standard 40-hour work week
needs to have five separate 40-hour working schedules configured.
:::

![All working schedules available to use currently set up in the database for the company.](working_schedules/working-schedules.png)

## New working schedule {#payroll/new-working-schedule}

To create a new working schedule, navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration -->
Working Schedules`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and click
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. The
`Working Schedules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} form has two
sections, a general information section and a
`Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab listing out all
the individual working hours by day and time.

Fill out the following information on the top-half of the form:

- `Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Type in the name for the
  new default working schedule. This should be descriptive and clear to
  understand, such as [Standard 20 Hours/Week]{.title-ref}.
- `Flexible Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Tick this
  checkbox if employees can work different hours from the working
  schedule.
- `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enter the
  number of hours per week an employee would need to work to be
  considered a full-time employee. Typically, this is approximately 40
  hours, and this number affects what types of benefits an employee can
  receive, based on their employment status (full-time vs part-time).
- `Average Hour Per Day`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: The average
  hours per day field is auto-populated, based on the working hours
  configured in the `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
  tab. This entry affects resource planning, since the average daily
  hours affect what resources can be used, and in what quantity, per
  workday.
- `Work Time Rate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: This percentage
  is auto-generated based on the entry for the
  `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the working
  hours configured in the `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} tab. This number should be between
  [0.00%]{.title-ref} and [100%]{.title-ref}, so if the percentage is
  above [100%]{.title-ref}, it is an indication that the working times
  and/or `Company Full Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} hours
  need adjustment.
- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the company that
  can use these new default working hours from the drop-down menu. A
  blank field indicates it is available for all companies.
- `Timezone`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Select the time zone to
  be used for the new default working hours from the drop-down menu.

Next, configure the individual hours in the
`Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab. This tab lists
the specific working hours for each day.

The `Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} are
auto-populated for a default 40-hour work week, with each day divided
into three timed sections.

Every day has morning (8:00-12:00), lunch (12:00-13:00), and evening
(13:00-17:00) hours configured.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `Work From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Work To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} times **must** be in a
24-hour format. For example, [2:00 PM]{.title-ref} is entered as
[14:00]{.title-ref}.
::::

Modify the `Day of Week`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Day Period`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Work Entry Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} selections by
clicking on the drop-down menus in each column and making the desired
selection. The `Work From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Work To`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} columns are modified by
typing in the time.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

Keep in mind, working hours are company-specific, and **cannot** be
shared between companies. Each company needs to have its own working
hours set.
::::

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If the working hours are not consistent each week, and the hours are on
a bi-weekly schedule instead, click the
`Switch to 2 week calendar`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button at
the top of the new default working hours form. This changes the
`Working Hours`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab to display two
weeks of working times that can be adjusted.
::::

![New working schedule form.](working_schedules/new-working-schedule.png)




--- SOURCE: hr/payroll.md ---

show-content

:   

# Payroll

Odoo\'s **Payroll** app is used to calculate employees\' worked time in
conjunction with other Odoo apps, such as **Employees**, **Time Off**,
**Attendances**, and **Planning**, and create corresponding payslips.

When an employee is hired, they must sign a
`contract <payroll/contracts>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}. The
contract outlines how the employee is compensated, including the salary
structure and rules their pay is calculated from, when they work (their
[working schedule]{.title-ref}), and what benefits they receive.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

It is critical to install the correct `country-specific localization
<payroll/payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, as this
configures all local and national rules, regulations, and applicable
taxes for the selected country.
::::

In addition to the employee contract, any
`salary attachments <payroll/salary_attachments>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"} must be configured before running payroll.

When it is time to run payroll according to the business\'s schedule
(monthly, weekly, bi-weekly, etc.),
`payslips <payroll/payslips>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} can be
created individually or in `groups
<payroll/pay_runs>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}. Odoo calculates when
the employees worked based on their `work entries
<payroll/work_entries>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}. Work entries are
created according to their `contracts
<payroll/contracts>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}, based on information
from the **Attendances**, **Planning**, or **Timesheets** apps. Any
errors with work entries **must** be resolved *before* continuing to
process payroll.

After all issues or conflicts are resolved, payslips are
`processed <payroll/process>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, and then
`employees are paid <payroll/pay-employee>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, either with a wire transfer or a physical check.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

It is possible to pay employees with cash, but this is not recommended.
::::

## Settings

Before running payroll, various settings for the **Payroll** app
**must** be configured. Navigate to
`Payroll app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. The various settings for
`accounting <payroll-accounting>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"},
`localizations <payroll-localizations>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"},
`time off
<payroll-time-off>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, and
`general payroll settings <payroll-payroll-settings>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} are specified here.

### Accounting {#payroll-accounting}

Configure the following in the accounting section of the configuration
menu:

- `Payroll Entries`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enable this
  option to post payroll slips in the **Accounting** app, in a
  [Salaries]{.title-ref} box on the main dashboard.
- `Payroll SEPA`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enable this option
  to create `SEPA (Single Euro Payments Area)`{.interpreted-text
  role="abbr"} payments.
- `Batch Account Move Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: Enable
  this option to have a single account move line created from all the
  accounting entries of the same period. This anonymizes accounting
  entries and disables the creation of individual payments.

### Localizations {#payroll-localizations}

*Localizations* are country-specific settings preconfigured in Odoo at
the creation of the database, which account for all taxes, fees, and
allowances for that particular country.

The `Localization`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section of the
**Payroll** app `Settings`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page
includes specific settings that need to be configured for the specific
country.

The settings and options shown in this section vary, depending on the
`localization enabled
<payroll/payroll_localizations>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} for the
database.

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::
